149358045.review:
[i]Faerie Solitaire[/i] is a nice, addictive game great for casual playing with a little twist to the classic Solitaire formula.

The story is simple but serves the purpose well so you don't aimlessly repeat one solitaire game after another. I liked the card's visual and background graphics which change accordingly to the story progression. The music is fine, voice acting though a little bit mediocre. But all in all, it works together.

There are 40 levels in total divided into 8 "worlds". Each level consists of 9 Solitaire games and a set of goals that have to be completed before moving to the next level. If you don't meet the goals you need to repeat the whole level, which can happen occasionally. As you clear the board from the cards you can uncover collectibles - various materials and eggs of magical creatures. When you find an egg you can then keep it on an active spot, where it will hatch as you play. If you have enough of the desired materials you can then evolve it! The pets are just collectible for your amusement and don't serve any other purpose, which is a shame on one hand, but when we consider the overall amount of pets (32), it would be a bit too much of a hassle to give them some active bonuses.
With every win, you are also collecting money which you can spend on getting sweet bonuses that are quite helpful in the long run.

My only complaint concerns the amount of grinding that is necessary for you to collect and evolve all the pets. Finding the collectibles is random and I simply didn’t have enough magic most of the time. ^^

As I said, [i]Faerie Solitaire[/i] is a good relaxing casual game. Just be prepared that one playthrough may not be enough for 100% completion.

139655601.review:
Faerie Solitaire: A Mediocre Card Adventure

Review:
Faerie Solitaire, unfortunately, falls short of its potential, and I can only give it a 2/5 rating. While it attempts to offer a unique twist on the classic solitaire gameplay, there are far superior solitaire games available that outshine it in terms of features and overall enjoyment.

One of the main drawbacks of Faerie Solitaire is its lack of innovation and depth. While it introduces some minor gameplay variations and incorporates a fantasy theme, it fails to offer the level of excitement and strategic depth found in other solitaire games. The mechanics quickly become repetitive, and the game fails to captivate and engage players over extended play sessions.

Moreover, the visual and audio aspects of Faerie Solitaire leave much to be desired. The graphics are rather simplistic and lacking in detail, failing to create an immersive and visually appealing experience. The sound design is also lackluster, offering little in terms of memorable music or atmospheric effects that enhance the gameplay.

In comparison to other solitaire games available on the market, Faerie Solitaire simply does not measure up. There are numerous alternatives that offer more engaging gameplay variations, challenging levels, and stunning visuals. These other solitaire games provide a more fulfilling and enjoyable experience, making Faerie Solitaire pale in comparison.

While Faerie Solitaire may appeal to some casual players or those specifically seeking a fantasy-themed solitaire experience, it pales in comparison to the many other superior options available. If you're looking for a solitaire game that offers more depth, innovation, and overall enjoyment, I recommend exploring the wide range of alternatives that exist.

Rating: ⭐⭐
A Mediocre Card Adventure: Faerie Solitaire falls short of its potential, lacking innovation and depth compared to superior solitaire games. With repetitive gameplay and subpar visuals, it fails to stand out in a genre with more engaging and fulfilling options.

97601631.review:
This is a simple game with a simple design -- flip cards to stack them in order, in either direction up or down the deck. So 3 can stack on 2 or 4, ace can stack on king or 2, and so on, opening the possibility for long combos juggled back and forth.

It isn't particularly fancy or especially beautiful. The story isn't very deep or engaging. There aren't too many extras (you can unlock a few useful skills which change gameplay a bit, and there is a very basic collection element). Honestly, it's not something that I would ordinarily have thrown a second glance at.

But I'm glad I did. I have now played this off an on for years, a few rounds at a time. Still haven't beaten it, and don't know if I ever will. There are so many levels that even with the visible progression bar it still feels nearly endless. It's addictive and pleasant.

Give it a chance.

Faerie Solitaire is exactly what it sounds like - solitaire with faeries; although you're saving the faeries. It's a very well put together game in the simplest aspects (unless your pushing for completion, then you must collect tons of eggs, level pets and beat some challenge modes).

Obviously it's fairly easy to understand how to play this game and beat each level without worry. Each area has a different soundtrack, but it's mostly like a background sound to me, not full on music.

As simple as they are, the scenes, backgrounds and card sets are pretty darn good. The story was quite good and engaging, especially because they put it in in such a neat way. After each stage, you get a short sentence or two of the story and a bigger cutscene version each chapter. It even CONTINUES into the next games!

If you enjoy solitaire games, I would give this one a shot. The difficulty mostly comes from trying to beat the challenge levels but again, most of those are pretty simple.

You can read my full review with stats here: https://jaderexeverythingsite.wordpress.com/2021/11/04/faerie-solitaire-remastered-game-review/

Gets a 'Not recommended' for two reasons.

75663189.review:
I remember when I was new(er) to Steam, Faerie Solitaire is one of the first games I remembering seeing in the store page.

When I did purchase Faerie Solitaire, it was in a shopping cart of other titles that I had found interesting, during a sale, in "2015". In the moment I write this review, on "9/8/'2020'", I can affirm that Faerie Solitaire stands above all of them.

__

The gameplay premise of Faerie Solitaire is as you may imagine: You play a lone game using an in-game typical, customized 52-card playing deck. I had no idea how to play Solitaire; thankfully the in-game tutorial explains it. These arrangements, each called "hands", come in groups of nine, and each five hands comprise a "chapter". Each chapter has different difficulties.

In addition to the basic card gameplay, the game has a "Fae village", or something to that effect. As one plays the card games, one amasses money. This money may then be spent on objects in this screen, which when activated will offer new abilities and tricks that will offer, in turn, new ways to play the game. This is one of the most impressive aspects of the game in my opinion, as it takes the simple premise of "solitaire", and turns it on its head in a way that empowers a user to devise skill and strategy to overcome the hurdles of randomness.

I've spent about five to ten minutes deliberating on how to represent Faerie Solitaire's visual and sound design in a way that avoids spoiling readers' expectations, and while keeping this review within Steam's character limit. I've chosen to simply say this:

The visual and sound design render an experience I for one consider enigmatic and wonder-inspiring, rendering indeed a sensation of the world itself being bigger than ourselves, and our role as indeed simply wandering through it, seeing it, hearing it - even as we're doing so by screens rather than a map, and we are somehow playing solitaire to pass the time.

The story, while admittedly rather corny, has come to grow on me. Admittedly, don't go in expecting much; the story's just a footnote in and of itself; its main victory is as a light first step into the SubSoap's flagship universe. While in this initial installment the universe isn't quite fleshed out [spoiler]as much as in later installments[/spoiler], various entries, the overworld map design, and the names and descriptions of events and places, give one's mind what is needed to piece together the beginnings of a varied world with life of its own.

In the way of gameplay, my recommendation is almost entirely pure. Each cited gameplay mechanic gives one what is needed to turn a simple solo card game into a strategy card game.

In the way of aesthetic, the game's position as a studio's first project does indeed show. The way the characters are drawn reminds me, frankly, of my own art style back in elementary school, being drawn in a sort off-key way that is not unsettling, but admittedly showing of newcoming to the world of drawing.

In this gentle, high-fantasy world, the protagonist- yes, there is a speaking, visually-designed protagonist- is a pale-skinned kid in late 90's/early 2000's-esque wear with his hair up like he's the son of a hair stylist and a coffee shop barista. In and of itself harmless, except he seems to be portrayed as already being part of this world rather than being warped into it.

This may just be my bias as a Tejano looking for a world to disappear in- or else liking when such different characters have an explanation for the mismatch- but this can break immersion just a tad when he's on-screen. Thankfully, when that happens, there are usually voluptuous fairy-girls in swimsuits on-screen to look at instead.

The wording for the pet entries is also oriented toward how ye contemporary whippersnappers speak, mixed in with the essence of a sales pitch. This does no harm, and its at any rate understandable given the open nature of taking one's first step into a new industry, as SubSoap has with Faerie Solitaire. My musings on this further would not fit in the remaining review character space.

Having played Faerie Solitaire for ninety hours and counting, I would say I've gotten well more than ten dollars' worth of enjoyment in my relaxing and getting lost in the Fae experience; however, I can understand that ten dollars may seem sketchy for a "simple" digital card game.

Faerie Solitaire is definitely a game to be played on and off over time when one wants to relax and enjoy oneself. Buying Fae Solitaire's like planting a fruit tree which may take a while to start growing fruit, and from which the fruits grow one at a time. Yet come those fruits do, and for a good long while. I've played about 90 hours and I intend to go back in after I'm done writing this review.

I fully recommend Faerie Solitaire, at full price, for those who would like a relaxing experience with a surprising amount of depth to it, with additional content to dig and find if you decide you'd like to, for those evenings you come home from work and just want a nice game to calm your nerves, and yet give your brain some easy exercise.

-Ryan Rodriguez/Ryarod/An Easy Target.

That is the best way I can describe it. I gave it a positive review because it did entertain me (even though I spent a few more hours in it than I would have liked to in order to get all the achievements). This game isn't really different from the one on your pc in terms of Solitaire mechanics, you get a few "power-ups" here and here but that's about it. The story isn't even something that atracts me at all which makes it very mediocre but I won't lie that I did get my fair share of enjoyment.

I enjoyed playing this game as a break between work I have to do or when I have some minutes to spare without anything else to do. I just wish it didn't take so long to evolve the pets and get the eggs. the first time I had it installed I tried getting all the eggs but the random drop effect made me stuck after replaying it over and over so it took me 2 years to come back and finish those achievements of getting all the eggs and evolving the pets.

The pets aren't useful at all, just a little extra to incentivize people to keep playing I guess. For me, the most fun is just the aspect of playing Solitaire and that on each aspect you have certain goals to achieve. Honestly, I do not know what happens when you fail to get them after the 9 rounds in the chapter because I've always been able to accomplish them.

So yeah. After all is said and done, I find this a mediocre but not of a game and if you are into Solitaire you might as well go for it if you happen to stumble upon it on discount or for free. If that happens, I hope you get some enjoyment out of it.

Faerie Solitaire lets you play Spider Solitaire with power ups.  For what it advertises, Faerie Solitaire delivers 100%.  I'm just not convinced that there's any need for this game.  What does Faerie Solitaire have over the classic Spider Solitaire preinstalled on most Windows machines?  The answer is Grind, the core game loop of Faerie Solitaire revolves around grinding hand after hand.

Story Mode is boring and artificially stretched out, slowly drip feeding you bits of dialogue every 9 hands.  The story isn't even good, the protagonist is annoying and incredibly unlikeable, constantly crying or running away.

Upgrades are expensive, you'll probably have to get through about 70% of story mode before earning enough money to buy all the upgrades.  Considering the length of the campaign it's a pretty significant grind.  Aura Ring is probably the most useful upgrade and synergizes well with extra undos once you figure out the trick to trigger a charge.

Challenge mode is difficult, but not because of anything interesting, rather the game just ramps up the level objectives presented in a typical game.  For example, instead of filling the purple bar in three minutes, you must do it in one.  You can cheese some of these stages by switching to Story mode to collect more Wild cards, but I think this was intended.

Getting 100% Achievements will force you to evolve all the pets (pets do nothing BTW), which is heavily RNG dependent as you need roughly equal amounts of the three droppable resources (Wood, Stone, and Magic).  Variance was the killer for me, by the time I finally got the last Stone I needed, I had in the excess of 33 Wood and 39 Magic.  Thanks to the statistics page, I was able to see I played through 625 hands of Faerie Solitaire before getting to 100%.

If you are looking for a casual Solitaire game, then Faerie Solitaire will offer you hours of consistent, if a bit boring gameplay.  Does it really innovate much over Spider Solitaire? Not really.

[h1]Solitaire Enhanced[/h1]
The base of this game is straight up solitaire but with a few changes and additions that make it more replayable and interesting to play. 
Like regular solitaire you flip through cards to match numbers/royal cards up and down however you don't get to cycle back through cards, you get one go through and that’s it for the level so you need to be careful and pick which direction is best to go with the cards to get the most out of each one. 

There are some objectives and features inside each level such as frozen or over grown cards that to unlock you need to remove the one selected card to continue which is best to try to get done asap so you don't get overwhelmed when you begin to run low on cards before tackling it. 
You can find eggs which you use XP earned through levels to upgrade them (purely cosmetic)
You earn money each level which you can use to get small upgrades like extra undo's, seeing the next card up etc

Really chill game to just play off to the side, stimulates your brain more than regular Solitaire and requires more thinking and thought to do well. 

[h1]8.2/10[/h1]
[i]- Brainless game that makes you use your brain[/i]

43368046.review:
I have just now started to play the Remastered version of this game, so I decided to make a review for the original.

Faerie Solitaire is a great simple card game for the casual gamer or the hardcore alike.... but mostly casual. 

A very atmospheric, mystical themed re-imagining on how to play a game of Solitaire. It's also an easier way to play Solitaire.
To be honest, despite the name, it's not really like how you play the real game of Solitaire. For one there's not different suits of cards. You might see multiple of the same card like an Ace or a 10 but there is no 10 of Diamonds and a 10 of Hearts or so on. Each card does have differences and even themes. Most have pictures of a creature on it. But they all act like they would be in the exact same suit if you were playing the real Solitaire. Just put a 2 on top of a 3, then put an Ace on that 2, followed by a king, then you can put an ace on the king again or a queen and so on and so forth. 

You play by trying to clear a full hand of Faerie land themed cards. They are laid out in front of you with some cards turned face up. you have a card drawn and a stack of cards beside it. Say your card is a 9. Look on the cards laid down and find either a 10 or an 8 to put on it. 
You can build up combos of cards to rack up more points and gold as well to buy upgrades for your Faerie Land. These upgrades grant things like more Undos, starting with the progress bar already partly filled, having the ability to peak at what the next card in your stack is, and even abilities like an Aura ring used to destroy any card you want after 7 moves of failing to move a card.

There are also Eggs you can find at random in this game. Which once hatched, become a baby creature. You can find magic dust, rocks, and wood under cards as well. And a varying number of each of these is needed to evolve each baby creature into an adult form. There are achievements for finding all the eggs and growing the pets. 
Now this is where the main complaint comes from for this game for most players. But is fixed in the remastered version.

Finding an egg is completely random chance. and the more rare eggs like the Rainbow eggs, for example, are even harder to find. It can take a very long time just grinding through the game over and over waiting for a random egg to appear under a stack of cards you clear. I personally played through the story mode 3 full times and was on my 4th run before I got the last egg. This makes getting those achievements a bit tedious and a ridiculous grind that takes hours. I think took me about 90 hours of game time to get mine. I've heard that some people have had to play for upwards of 150 hours before they get their last egg. It's all random chance. 

This though, has of course been fixed in the new version of the game. Where they added a time cap to how long it can go between eggs you find. So if you go for too long of time the game will give you an egg at mercy anyways.  A nice improvement.

Also in this game you have a Spare card system that you can unlock. Where you can get cards 2 through 10 as spares and on the side of the screen. Just clicking one puts it on top of your hand and changes the card there to give more options on how to play and rack up even higher combos.

There are even some obstacles on the cards. Some stacks will be covered in thorns and cant be played until you finish a different stack and get the roots under it. And some cards are frozen in ice. The ice ones there is also a fire card in one of the stacks which you have to get and it melt's the ice card making them playable. It's a fun little feature.

The game's story is actually not bad. And surprisingly deep for something like Solitaire. But I won't go into details of what the story is, I'll leave that for you to discover. :D

The voice acting by the main character can be slightly annoying at time with his over dramatic delivery of the lines, but other than that he does a fine job.

Over all I give this game a great thumbs up but I will lessen it's score a little due to the Egg achievement issue. Which was fixed in the remastered version.
I give this game an 8 out of 10.

40859550.review:
[h1] Verdict: 6/10 [/h1]

Nice enough PC implementation of typical card solitaires. A light story and challenge modes are available. Time killer that would be appreciated by the fans of the genre despite resolution limitations and dated graphics.

[h1] PrivateJoh’s personal (re)view: [/h1]

I find Faerie Solitaire a fair implementation of a typical card solitaire. It offers challenge and story modes.

Challenge mode is what you would expect. Complete certain goals to beat the challenge.

The story mode is quite banal, but I guess it fulfills its purpose. It is divided in stages, which are subsequently divided in challenges. In order to complete each of these challenges, certain requirements have to be met. In the process, money will be earned and spent buying certain buffs that will help complete the missions. The game can be played in 3 difficulty levels, which means quite a few hours just for the story mode.

The main criticism stems from the technical aspects. The game has a really defined dated look, with subpar graphics and resolution limitations. 

[b] In summary [/b]; a well executed PC implementation of a card solitaire that will serve as a time killer for fans of the genre.

For more PrivateJoh’s personal (re)views you can check [url=http://store.steampowered.com/curator/32042143-PrivateJoh%27s-personal-%28re%29views/] HERE [/url].

38613017.review:
Edit: Game seems to be making use of false reviews (reviews by employees or reviews paid for. Such as a positive review saying "Hello!". Recommend reporting developer & score dropped to 1 out of 10.

After spending 71 hours to get all the "pet" drops in this mediocre game I'm done with it.

It's not amazing, the "story" & gameplay mechanics are actually annoying & the only reason I was able to stand finishing it is because I enjoy card games.

I thought "whatever... not a game worth any more time".

Than I heard that they were making "Faerie Solitaire Remasted". Same crap but they're wanting $10.

That was too much... it went from a game that didn't deserve any more attention to a game that needed more attention to post a negative review for so ppl understand it's a game barely woth buying.

Out of 10 with 10 being the best & 1 being garbage:

Audio: 3/10. After 71 hours of the "music" if I ever hear another note of it I'll pour bleach in my ears.

Visuals: 4/10 Standard card art, rest of the art is mediocre stuff their artist threw out in a couple weeks.

Gameplay: 5/10. The best part of the game... it does put a couple interesting mechanics on the Solitaire game model but not enough to make it a game worth having outside a collection of Solitaire. There's goals to meet to end each level & the desgin of the game has made it so that sometimes, apparently randomly, you'll get levels that are not winable no matter how good you are. To get all the "pets" to finish the game 100% expect to spend dozens if not hundreds of hours trying to get the random drops. Took me 71 hours. I read at some point of someone who was in the hundreds. I get the impression most ppl put in around 50. Artificial game length.

Controls: 1/10? I mean... it's a one button mouse game... I dunno if that's honestly good or bad.... it's just... umm... minimal?

Story: 2/10 There is a story. You won't care. Something about faries. Completely superfluous to game play but at least they tried?

Over all 3/10. Not one to buy.. but it is only a dollar. This is more a cautionary review to say that the "remasted" edition is far, far overpriced.

36676261.review:
I was hoping to unlock all the achievements before writing a review for this game, but I've lost my patience so easily, that I decided to delete everything and put an end to this whole thing.

Wow, I've gotta be careful, you might actually think that this is a bad game after reading such a brutal introduction, isn't? Well, it's actually a very fun game. It can get quite addicting too, if you're not careful enough. Playing cards, right?

Anyway, so what is this title about? The name pretty much summarizes everything. The only thing is that there's also this background story and objectives to be fulfilled, in order to try to keep the player more immersed in that realm. I didn't pay much attention to the story, to be quite honest. I just wanted to beat every level as fast as possible while I was playing.

Now for an overview: The graphics are ok, I only thought annoying the fact that the full screen resolution is so awful. The sound effects can get really annoying after some time. The music is ok, I actually loved one of the songs available. As for the gameplay mechanics, besides the premise of solitaire, there're also some RPG elements. The more combos you make, the more money you get. With that cash, you get to unlock certain power-ups that can help you a lot. You can also get to find some resources every now and then some eggs, but I'll have to get back to that in the next paragraph.

Ok, so there're also trading cards (which are always nice), and some achievements to unlock. And that's the part where this game kicks you in the nuts. Well, you can get more than 90% of the achievements just by playing the regular game, no big deal, right? Now, if you want to get every single one available, get ready for an endurance round. Remember the eggs from before? There're lots of them, and every now and then (really rare), you get to find one in the levels. After you find them, you can hatch them, and also evolve them through the experience points that you gather while playing it (it takes ages, just for the record). There's actually an update which actually allows you to purchase the eggs you couldn't find so far, but the prices (which are already expensive), rises exponentially. So, what do you do? You check the community guides, and what do you find? Everything is about those stupid eggs!

So, overall, how obnoxious could these devs be, to the point of basically pushing the players to their limits just for the sake of a couple achievements. This is simply ridiculous, you just don't do that, especially when you're planning to release a sequel.

Ok, now that the ranting is over, this is a fun game, really. Just be careful with the "Platinum" trap. It's surely not worth it. If you doubt what I'm saying, I read that there was this guy who had to play this thing for more than 225 hours just to find all the eggs. Have friggin' mercy...

Essentially what this game is is golf solitaire with some bells and whistles (powerups, a storyline mode, etc.).

Faerie Solitaire is a very fun Card game. 
The basics are easy to udnerstand - Solitaire. The game adds a few features to spice things up such as special hidden cards, collectables, locked cards, special effects & more. 

The campaign is pretty common - good guy vs bad guy - save fairies - rescue the world. Nothing special, but realized well. 
The game lenght is okayish, as i finished the game in slightly over 12 hours. A challenger mode is also included to let players meet certain goals and gain rewards. Just another bonus to this great game. 

The only downside i have ever encoutnered was the insane amount of time it can take to complete a specific achievement - gathering all pets. This is purely based on your luck and there are reports of people playing well over 40 hours and not finding all of them. Not very nice, but not game breaking. 

Overall fully recommended to lovers of the card game genre or people who are looking for a relaxing and yet chellenging game. If you are only here for another +1 finished game - don't bother.

30645073.review: Faerie Solitaire is just that, standard solitaire built into Windows with a little fairy dust on top in the form of colorful wallpapers and unlockable abilities that make solving puzzles easier. Everything else is just baggage that sinks the entire experience: horrible forever-alarmed narrator, forgettable cliche of a story that has the player rescuing fairies over and over ad nauseum, and collectible purely-cosmetic pets that serve no purpose and are just busy-work tied to achievements, to keep people playing. Pets drop when completing stacks of cards, and may require hundreds of hours of gameplay to complete the collection due to the random nature of the drops. Completing game levels offers little more in terms of excitement and comes down to playing 9 games of solitaire per level, while accomplishing up to 3 objectives, like getting a certain score or finishing in a certain time frame. Achieving objectives early still forces the player to play through all 9 games, and failing objectives to replay all 9 games again. There is no way to lose, short of quiting and not getting to the end (guess what, you rescue the fairies and defeat evil), which brings me back to my original point - there is no game here, besides the basic solitaire that everyone can already play for free.

A variation on Tripeaks solitaire card game. Cute story, if a bit dark.  Good casual time waster if that is what you are looking for. Well programmed and no real bugs.

I recommend this game with a few warnings:

1) Be prepared to spend a lot of time at it if you are achievement hunting. I am fairly good at Tripeaks, and have all of the chapters done, plus all the bonus challenges. By the time you do those, you have plenty of materials needed for the pets.  Balance wise, those aspects are perfect. What isn't balanced right is the "time played" needed to hatch each pet. I am literally grinding playing casual just to get enough time for each to hatch, nothing else.  Wondering at this point if I really WANT those last two achievements.

2) As others have said, wait for a sale. Not worth the full $10 but have seen it down to a few dollars or 99 cents.

3) The storyline is a bit dark. Cute faeries and all, but all through the game the story tries to be suspenseful and ends up just plain depressing with no real closure.  Ends on a note implying there will be a Faerie Solitaire 2, but after 6+ years I highly doubt it.

Overall, at the current sale price, this game will entertain you for at least a few hours (I'm already 2-3 hours into it and have plenty to go). The pets are a great addition, and I enjoy collecting them and evolving them. The main negative is that I noticed a spelling error on one of the powerups, were it says "you" when it should say "your." If you can handle that mistake (I haven't noticed other spelling or grammar errors), and you want a casual game that you can play for a few minutes or a couple hours (I'm oddly addicted), I think this game might just be for you.

28669087.review:
Solitaire isn't something I care much about, I was here just for the achievements. For this reason I thought long and hard on whether it is fair for me to give a negative review to Faerie Solitaire, considering that the core gameplay - the solitaire - is solid. There are a bunch of mechanics to remove cards, add cards and various initial layouts. It's still very repetitive, but I guess fans of the genre accept that.

The graphics are terrible, I hated them. And no, I don't mean the technical aspect because I understand a game from 2010 might have aged poorly. The art direction is just abysmal, the colour palette, the ugly faces of the faeries, all of it was continuously driving me up the wall. The story is annoying, the voice acting is annoying. The pet system does [i]nothing[/i], it feels like it was slapped on as faux-content. The base building system is okay but you run out of upgrades quickly and then there is nothing to do with money. The last two achievements require so much grinding it would put some Korean MMOs to shame. 

I suspect there is a target demographic out there that loves this sort of combination (otherwise it wouldn't have 91% positive reviews at the time of writing), but I have found myself too far removed from it to be able to give a thumbs up.

This is not a good game, but you will enjoy it so much.

Seriously, this game does nothing particularly well, but it will still entertain you for hours as you shuffle cards around like a moron.  You will ask yourself, "Why am I not playing something good?  Why am I wasting my limited hours on Earth playing Faerie Solitaire?"  And then you will start the next level and then ten hours have passed and your children are crying and it is dark outside and you have a pounding hunger headache and your clothes smell.  "Just one more level," you will say.  "Just one more level of this terrible, barely competent game that I can't stop playing."  

But it is never just one more level.  Because it has the strings of your soul now and it is knitting a dark and terrible pattern from those threads.  Soon the end times will come.

"If I were to publicly admit to playing a casual solitaire game on Steam, there is a good chance it might be this one."  - Greg

For a card game like this, I think the plot isn't that new. It's not bad, but nothing special or exciting either. It had a twist that I guessed long before it was revealed, but it didn't really matter. The game's about matching cards anyway.

The "map" is the only thing that bothered me because I never saw my "progress" or location in the game. Or if I could see it somewhere, I didn't [i]see[/i] if you understand what I'm saying.

About gameplay. I liked the eggs the player could find and how they hatched into different beings and gave us a little info about the animal. HOWEVER. 25769142.review:
Compared to its namesake, Solitaire, Fairie Solitaire is a game that is simple to a fault. Cards are setup in a formation on the board and the player has to chain them together in continuous sequential chains (8 > 9 > 10 > 9 > 10 > J > Q, etc). That's all there is to it. Really. Suit and colors don't matter and may as well not be there at all.

What you see on the first level is pretty much what you get for the entire game, and it makes the game just about as mind-numbingly easy and repetitive as you would expect. Even the "challenge" maps don't really offer a notable increase in difficulty. Other gameplay mechanics that are introduced a little ways into the adventure mode, such as thorns and ice walls, are actually the exact same as the usual mechanics - the only difference between these mechanics and conventionally blocked stacks of cards is a graphical effect. The upgrade system is mostly inconsequential, granting little bits of extra info or allowing room for error. The Aura Ring is the only upgrade that comes close to being significant in the long run, adding a way to occasionally force a card off of a stack. Unfortunately, its high cost means it won't be available until the mid-to-late game.

That's pretty much all there is to the gameplay, so what about all the dressings? Unfortunately, there isn't much to speak of here either. The soundtrack gets repetitive pretty quickly. The storyline is pretty generic and leaves off on an annoying cliffhanger for a sequel that doesn't exist (and considering the fact that this game came out 6 years ago by now, probably never will exist). Completing adventure mode didn't take me even half as long as the alleged 14 hours mentioned in the description (which, to be honest, is probably for the best). The 40 unique locations are nothing more than different forgettable graphical backdrops. 

The pet system feels tacked on and unneccesary. Finding and evolving them is just a matter of grinding the game out until you're lucky enough to randomly find the eggs and evolution resources. Preparing a given pet for evolution is a pure time sink, done in the background automatically while you play the game normally. The only thing evolution grants you is a small image of your fully grown pet alongside a descriptive sentence or two. There's absolutely no incentive to grind for pet evolution aside from this and a couple steam achievements. Incidentally, if you are going for said achievements, you can probably expect to sink ~50 hours into the game after completing a <10 hour story mode, if I had to guess.

Just about the only thing positive I have to say about the game is that the artwork for the world map and the cutscenes looked fairly nice.

If you want a casual card game and traditional Solitaire is too challenging for you, then maybe this is worth considering. As for me, I think I'll stick with the one bundled with Windows to scratch that itch.

This is a really good, frustrating, challenging and fun card game. It seems simple, but there are times the cards just won't give you a break. It's got a cute story in the Adventure mode, which is what I've been playing. There are several other modes to offer a challenge and change things up.

I've been going at this one for a while, card games aren't usually my cup of tea. I've played other card games like HearthStone and Magic, but this one isn't like those. It's not a competition against someone else. It's trying to achieve the goals set to complete that level. Not always an easy task either.

One thing I discovered later in the game was the faerie land. Check there soon as you discover an egg under one of the cards in the game. I was surprised to find several eggs when I looked into the hatchery! I didn't even know about this area, I hadn't really looked around.

The pets once hatched gain EXP while you play, so I lost a lot of leveling time for these pets since I didn't know I had them. You can also get special boosts to help during game play too.
Now I've got to level up a few pets to see what happens! I thought I was almost done with the game!

I really liked this, despite being a card game, I found it to be a really good game.  Plus there are other elements, replaying levels, harder challenges with bonuses and pets to level too. I'd recommend it to those that like puzzles and card games.

25329322.review:
[h1]Summary:[/h1]
Honestly...what is there to complain about?  Faerie Solitaire is as you can imagine a solitaire game, with enough interesting dynamics and collectibles in-game to keep you interested.  If you like a good old traditional game of solitaire with some new twists, and maybe want to play a game you can pass the time with while you are also doing other things, this is a good bet.  This game tends to be on sale or in bundles with reasonable frequency, so I'd try to keep your eyes peeled so you don't have to pay the full price tag however.  It has equal parts addictiveness and mindlessness that make it a good go to if you want to pass the time.

[h1]Pros:[/h1]
[*]Simple and effective UI layout.  Within your first round of playing you'll see the "twist" that they have put onto solitaire and will be able to pick things up rather easily.
[*]I like that they added collectibles in the form of pets into the game.  What is more motivating then winning?  Winning and also getting that fat loot!
[*]This is a great game to run in windowed mode in a low resolution and work on something else or kick some Netflix in.  While it takes a good amount of thought process to get the best possible card outcomes, it can still be done without laser focus.
[*]They try to inject some story into the game, but at the same time don't push it down your throat.  The story isn't memorable, but for this type of game should it need to be?  They did a solid job of letting you skip what you don't want to see, and just play some cards.[/list]


[h1]Cons:[/h1]
[*]The level or stage progression feels a little wonky.  You can see the levels represented at the top-left of your screen for each world, but at the same time it could have been more clearly represented.
[*]They could have probably added more playtime into the game if you could also use your cash for buying things for your pets.  Mostly specific to upgrades that will give you advantages in the game (more undo chances, more cash, etc.)
[*]The full price tag on this game could probably be called pretty steep.  While I enjoyed this game, I can't imagine spending more than $5 on a game which is fundamentally based on solitaire.[/list]


[i]If you liked this review or want to see more recommended games, be sure to follow our curator group: [url=http://steamcommunity.com/groups/Original_Curators_Group#curation]Follow Original Curator Group[/url]

23734534.review:
Fun variation on Tri Peaks solitaire.  If all you're into is playing cards, you will enjoy this game.  The art style was bright and colorful, which I loved.  The story was decent until the ending.  The developers clearly intended to make a sequel as they ended the story without any resolution, which was disappointing.  The concept of collecting eggs and hatching them using gathered resources is great, but the execution falls flat. 

The egg drop rate is too high overall as often after hatching/raising an egg you will have several other eggs already waiting in your inventory.  I don't think I ever ran out of the resources to hatch eggs either, making them rather useless.  I never had the opportunity to plan out what egg to hatch based on resources because I always had more than enough.  The rarest eggs do take longer to drop but they are manageable.  I think I had all but one egg hatched by the time I finished the story.  That dreaded last egg though.  Apparently it purposefully has a very low drop rate and I have given up on trying to get it after playing through the story twice, doing all the challenges, and countless free plays.  It leaves a bad taste that after getting all of the other eggs with ease, the last is designed to be next to impossible to get.  If you have to force people to continue playing your game by holding one last achievement over their head, then you are too insecure about your game.   It turns the game into a grind.  I don't start up the game thinking "Yay I can relax and play some solitaire for fun", but rather "Maybe this is the time I'll finally get lucky". I think this was a poor design decision that drains the fun.

If you are considering buying this game for the easy achievements, don't.  The last egg takes forever to drop and you will become very frustrated waiting for it.  If you are looking at this game because you like solitaire, go for it.

23307611.review:
Alright game. Nothing special, but you can spend some time with it.

The basic idea is pretty close to your average solitaire, but with some twists to make the game more interesting. Such as thorn-covered cards, which you need to uncover by getting rid of another pile first, or frozen cards that you need to melt with a 'fireblast' card in some other pile, which you need to get rid of first. Also, there are unlockable power-ups of sorts. In its core, though, it still is a pretty simple solitaire-like game, so it does get repetitive and boring pretty fast. Unless you are into that sort of games, of course.

I do recommend the game, as it has a pretty original feeling to it, it's made pretty well (despite looking pretty amateurish here and there — such as the pets, I'd say), and even has an adventure mode with a voice-acted story. Besides, despite it starting to feel repetitive to me, I still kept playing it for some reason, haha.

23279810.review:
Pros: Interesting mechanics, challenging levels even on easy mode, good visuals, a pretty solid story with an okay ending. Also just a great game of solitaire. 

Cons: If you're someone who needs to get a hundred percent, this game becomes a time-sink as you play levels over and over to search for the last few eggs to hatch and mature. To date, I've dropped 193 hours on the game and am still missing the last three or so eggs. Also after you buy all the enhancements, there's nothing left to do with the money so it just piles up uselessly.  Not a whole lot of replay value, at least not in terms of going back to the very beginning. Once the story is over it's pretty much over.  

Summary: A great game if you just want to play unique hands of solitaire. Interesting mechanics and visuals. But very difficult to 100% and not in a hard way but in a time slogging way. Replay value is low. And I would have preferred a better ending honestly.

22414223.review:
[h1] Divertido Juego de Solitario [/h1]

Faerie Solitaire es una de las tantas variaciones del famoso Solitario. Así que , directamente a quienes les guste jugar al solitario, este juego no defraudará. 

Básicamente tiene 2 modos principales, el modo historia, en donde se nos presenta la historia del juego y un modo desafio. 
Cada stage esta dividido en 9 niveles , en donde tendremos que intentar despejar todas las cartas para poder lograr un Perfect. Cada stage tiene uno o mas objetivos , siendo estos necesarios para pasar al siguiente stage (tanto en el modo historia como completar cada desafio). Los objetivos no son nada del otro mundo, son del tipo obtener un combo de X cartas, hacer X cantidad de perfects por stage, etc). 

A su vez, el juego tiene una especie de store, llamada Faery Land, donde podremos comprar mejoras para el juego (como ser poder ver la siguiente carta a droppear, poder tener comodines, etc), y tambíen donde tenemos unos coleccionables que vamos encontrando en los niveles.

La música, graficos y ambientación del juego son muy buenos, y suficientes para este tipo de género. Es divertido y adictivo.

 En resumen , un buen juego, divertido, y por supuesto recomendado.

22182667.review: Faerie Solitaire, as if you couldn't guess, is a solitaire game. It has a few things to make it different from being just regular solitaire. Sometimes you can't begin to work on a stack until you clear another stack first, and sometimes you need to activate a fire blast card to melt a frozen pile. There are also some things that can help you such as being able to undo a move and other unlockable benefits. You have to rescue a fairy by clearing enough cards across nine games, in addition to completing objectives like completing a game under a certain amount of time or getting a perfect game. There's not much else to say about this one, if you like solitaire, you'll probably like this game.

21896282.review:
I'm sure everyone and their mother has written reviews about the damn eggs, so allow me to instead focus on a question I had for the entire duration of this game: Why do the cards have suits? The instructions take care to note that the suit of the cards don't matter, so why did the designers bother giving the cards suits at all? They already gave them custom images based on the pets, so they could've elminated card suit all together and streamlined the instructions. As it stands the suits only serve as a distraction.

That aside, I do enjoy this game. It's fun to figure out the best sequence of cards, and the longer the chain you're able to string the more satisfying it feels to end the combo. I thought the ending was far too abrupt, but considering that the story is thin and non-essential in the first place I suppose I shouldn't complain... BUT I'm going to anyway: The crying fairies got old fast. I'd like to see them... y'know, do something. They're magical flying glowy things; I have to imagine they're capable of more than crying at the protagonist.

But, I digress. The game's fun enough, although maybe not $10's worth of fun. If you catch it when it's at least half off, I do recommend giving it a go. Just try to keep your blood pressure down if you decide to go for the damn eggs (especially since the pets you hatch don't even do anything for you).

When I first bought this game, I thought it was going to like a normal solitaire game, but it is actually a different kind of solitaire called tripeaks solitaire. At first I was confused, but I got the hang of it pretty fast and now I think its a really fun game.

21675685.review:
You can't go wrong with solitaire. Faerie Solitaire is the game that everyone has played at some point in their life plus a story, rpg elements such as exp and upgrades, and some pleasant background noise. 

.Game play. 
Your objective is to count. You have a deck of cards from which you draw one card and then you try and place it on a card on the game board before you that either precedes it or follows it--i.e, if you have a 6, you can place it on a 5 or 7. It's very simple and very satisfying if you can get a good count running. Some boards have a gimick such as ice that can be removed if you clear the cards in front of a 'fireball' spell and thorns that can be removed if you clear the row of cards over their roots.

Besides that, you sometimes find eggs if you clear the rows of cards on the board and you can equip the pets inside of them so that they passively gain experience while you play. The pets evolve using ingredients you can find the same way you find their eggs, but their only function is for vanity (and achievements).

.Story/Premise.
You're trying to save the Faerie Land and you progress through each area by playing solitaire. It doesn't make much sense, but... Magic!

.Art style/graphics.
It's colourful and cartoony. The illustrations on the cards and for the pets are cute and the animations for the spells you cast or the combo meter are neat.

.Soundtrack.
It's peaceful. Suitable for a card game.

.Bottom line. 
There's not much else to say. Faerie Solitaire is a nice way to pass the time. Definitely worth a look.

21549880.review:
An entertaining Solitaire game, with quite simple, but engaging gameplay; and a nice story about faeries. This game is good for some relaxing during an afternoon; even though it's simple, there's still some challenge to it. The aesthethic is really nice, featuring some nice backgrounds for each of the different levels, all following a fantasy theme.

The game offers several modes; an adventure mode, in which you play through 40 levels, following the story of a kid who encountered faeries, and all the dangers he encountered during his journey to save them which, although might sound unnecessary for a solitaire game, adds a nice backstory. There's also a quickplay mode, in which you can replay any previously finished level, and a challenge mode, with some more difficult levels. Each level consists of 9 hands, and, while it's not necessary to collect all cards in each hand, there's still different objectives to complete in order to beat a level.

The game also includes a "Faerie Land"; think of it as an upgrade/collectibles shop, where you can get several different upgrades spending money you earn during the game, and also a hatchery for all the different pets you may encounter while you play. It is a nice addition to the game, giving it a bit more of depth.

As far as soundtracks go, it consists of several relaxing songs that play during each level, providing a calm environment while you play.

All things said, I think this is a recommendable solitaire game, for when you want some casual, relaxing fun.

Solitaire with a twist, plain and simple.

Now, it does get repetitive.  Great for casuals who want to be rewarded with a story for completing objectives.  .....Then there's the notorious achievements where you have to either play a million games or use an auto-click script to unlock the last eggs for the final 2 achievements.  (All Eggs and All Pets)  And for full price ($10), the game simply isn't worth the price.   It often goes on sale for a price of $1 or $2, if you're interested in this game, try to grab it during a sale.

7/10  Great for casual gamers, but it's not without flaws.

19450382.review:
This game is fantastic. Sure it's 'just solitaire', but then again, it's not just solitaire. Subsoap has taken the simple tripeaks concept and added in features to add a bit of interest. For example, there are board mechanics that hide cards until you reveal a trigger element. Or a grabber that you can use to grab one card off the table after 5 draws without a hit from the table. I'm on my second play through of the story mode after 30 hours of play and it's still enjoyable.
They added a bit of story that, while not great, adds a bit of interest at the end of the levels. They also have challenges to beat such as finish a deck in 1 minute (hard), or get a run of 15 cards (much easier), etc.
Each number has its own image on the card meaning it's easy to learn the images and see the cards quickly.
The sounds are spectacular. There is a calm piano in the background as well as a sound themed to the story area you are in. These background sounds are high quality and I love listening to them. The wind in the snowy mountains is my favorite (I wish I could get a copy of the wind sound's source!), the crackling fire in the volcano sounds like a fireplace, and the chirping birds in the forests are clear and crisp. Sometimes I'll just start a game for the background sounds.
I picked it up in a steam sale (or humble bundle, I can't remember now), but for how much time I've put into it, I'd consider buying it at full price, definitely at half price, 75% off would be a steal.

19225707.review:
So I’m a stickler for Steam Trading Cards but I refuse to be one of those people that actually buys the cards. No, I wanna get cards through playing games because I feel like I’ve worked for them and also I get to play things.So I usually look for cheap stuff on Steam and I found this game called Faerie Solitaire and it had a pretty okay rating and it was under a dollar, so I was like, “why not?”

Anyway, the game is basically Solitaire but easier and wrapped in a fantasy setting. There’s a story, but there’s no real relationship between the gameplay and the story so it definitely feels like an excuse plot; the art for the cutscenes is nice though. However, because of the added gameplay elements (like being able to change the number of your current card) and the removal of some (suites don’t matter in Faerie Solitaire), Faerie Solitaire’s easier experience grabbed me. Okay tranquil music plays while you’re playing and it feels like a zen experience. Levels give you objectives to meet before you clear all the hands in a stage, but except for the challenge levels, you can probably meet those objectives with no problems.

If I had a gripe with the game it’d definitely be the egg mechanic. You sometimes find eggs while playing the game and you can hatch it to get a creature, and the creature you have with you gains experience as you play until you’re able to evolve it. The problem is that the drop rates of the eggs suck; if the steam discussions can be believed, it honestly seems like an everyone problem than a me problem. Like sure, these creatures have no additional gameplay benefits aside from being a thing, but if you’re a stickler for accomplishing everything in a game, the drop rates of the eggs makes it aggravating as the last two achievements is hatching all the eggs and evolving all the creatures.

But yeah aside from egg hell the game’s okay. I liked to play it while watching something in the background and if the drop rate stuff gets fixed I can go back to it and finish everything I guess. If you like solitaire but also hate it here’s the middle ground you need I guess.

For a solitarie, it's has some nice earned buff elements to it as you gain in game money to buy special skills. You have to make the level goals if you want to continue. It has a story line as well. You can find pets, hatch them and resources to "evolve" them. There's wild cards. The playing field has cards frozen with ice, covered with thorned rose vines, etc. It also has in game and Steam acheivements, cards, etc. It's not hard - it's solitarie, just not boring old solitarie your grandparents play.

It plays on Windows, Mac. And a super secret Linux verions, if you own it on Steam. In the app's property details, you can join the Faerie Solitaire beta for Linux (the Linux version is not available else where anymore.)

19167717.review:
I'm about halfway through the game at the time of writing this, and let me just say that this game is addicting. It is 'solitaire', only it's done a little bit differently, with you matching the current card in your hand with cards that are either one card higher or one card lower, so if you've got a 5, you can click on a 4 or a 6, and you can keep on going to build up combos (5, 6, 5, 6, 7, 6, 5, 4, 3, 2, A, K, A, 2, etc. and so forth). On top of the simple but attractive game mechanics, you have a story going on behind the scenes, but it's not something you will find you will pay much attention to. As you play, you earn money that you use to buy buildings in Faerie Land which yield you bonus abilities during gameplay (the Aura Ring is very helpful for those pesky cards you just can't match!). Also, you find resources and creature eggs while playing, and you can hatch the eggs, build up the creature's XP, then evolve them to adulthood with the resources you've gathered. So you've got solitaire, a fantasy RPG, and animal caretaking(?) all wrapped up into one. 

10/10 way more compelling than boring old Windows Solitaire

Kinda... way too generic for my taste.

In other words, this game intentionally lowers your testosterone level, which may be good, if you're having some health issues, but it is quite boring in the most cases. Well, even if you DO need to lower testosterone level or don't care for that matter at all... sadly, but besides of being an easy game about saving fairies, that thing doesn't bring any noticeable amounts of pleasure or complacency I usually expect.

I must say there: I'm speaking about one particular game! I've spent hundreds of hours in games like "Plants vs. Zombies", "World of Goo", "Zuma", or my favourite there on Steam - "Shufflepuck Cantina"... Really, there are many non-violent casual games which I prefer over shooters like Crysis... only thing I care is it fun and satisfying or not.

I've played hundreds of thousands solitaire games, while idling... you know, when you listening to some podcast, awaiting in some queue, or something like that - the windows basic set of games is always a relief, if you don't have a book or something greater to do. The basic solitaire game doesn't need too much attention - you can play it, while there are something else is going, and it can be a moving meditation of sort... but it is not about Faerie Solitaire. There are too many insignificant details, that always keep you a bit distracted by themselves. So to play that game you actually need full observation. And there are way too little to do in there with the full attention. A paradox. Relatively speaking, you can't play it with one eye, and it is not worth to stare at with both eyes.

To finish talking about that game, there is one of those hatred luck-based achievements, which you can try to unlock by ages.

In sum, it is a small casual game, which you can gift to some non-gaming girl. Or your mother, maybe... However, to play in it by yourself, even if you're a girl, yet from our gaming breed... Now that's a low move.  5/10 mark.

17786236.review:
Faerie Solitaire is a far better game than it has any right to be. As someone who's never dabbled much into solitaire, I figured I would spend an hour looking at this and chuckle at the whole thing. Weirdly, even though the story is a wonderful schlockfest of campy tropes and no connection to the actual gameplay or goals whatsoever, I couldn't stop playing.

Solitaire is a simple and admittedly boring game, one that is meant to pass time when there is nothing else to do and no one to play with. With only the lightest added perks such as monster collecting, light goals to reach, interesting card set ups and the removal of having to match specific suits, FS turns the whole trite affair into an exciting and wildly engaging affair that I couldn't put down for the next 3 days. I found it best served with some podcasts in the background so as not to feel like I was wasting my life away, but there is an amazing amount of content her from such a simple concept.

After it got its hooks in me, every hand I practically twitched when I didn't clear the boardfor fear of missing out on a new monster egg for my collection that might've been hidden behind those last two cards. The impressive difficulty curve the game presents is also kind of amazing, which is not something I was expecting at all. Fascinatingly complex set ups can lead to a surprising amount of forethought and tactical card plays that can make or break a run. Of course, like all games that surround the old 52, there is no garuntee you'll be able to clear the board, but Faerie offers a variety of unlockable tools that make the prospect more and more plausible. One tool in particular can save a hand for total defeat, in which if you can't make a move in 5 turns, you can zap a card and make it your base. It adds an extra layer to an already complex layer of moves, and once I got into the grove I could rip through hands at unbelievable speed. It's hard to describe just how rewarding this game can be without playing it yourself.

Of course, there are flaws. Plenty of them. The art used to differentiate the cards are not very appealing, the soundtrack can become grating, and the voice-acted story is cheesy and oh so teeth-grindingly bad. Somehow, though, this doesn't detract, but somehow amplifies the glory of this weird little game. While I wasn't neccessarily chomping at the bit to hear the next chapter in the riveting saga, there is a genuine aloof passion to the whole story that I can't help but admire. There is tons of great art in the game that just didn't seem to get used on the cards, but they do help stimulate recognition, to the point where I stopped paying attention to the numbers all together. This is not to say the art is bad; quite the contrary, but that goblin they put on the king cards really begged for a punch in the face. Of course for the soundtrack, you can always turn the music off and put something more to your taste on.

Not exactly a game I expected to like, and definitely not a game I'd come to love. Faerie Solitaire is the sort of guilty pleasure I never thought I wanted. I can't recomend this lovely pile of cheese enough.

This is a beautiful, fun game with lots of replay value (even after you've gotten all the achievements). The art and the story are unique and give lots of character to what might otherwise be just another solitaire game, and the addition of the creature hatching/growing up mechanic guarantees at least two runs through adventure mode; I got the two hardest achievements right at the end of my third run, but I think that was pure luck. The music and sound are both done very well and are non-intrusive, and the voice acting for the story interludes (which can be skipped) is very good, especially for such a small game. I got it for the absolute lowest price ever of 49 cents, but if I had disposable income I'd willingly pay full price for it. Even with all the achievements done, I'll be coming back to it to play more, because it's a good time killer, and is relaxing enough to play before bed. [b]9/10[/b], my only complaints are that it IS addicting, and that I wish it had more levels in challenge mode.

Edit, 11/22/17 - I still love this game, and it continues to be rewarding because whenever I hatch and raise all my creatures, I delete the files for the in-game achievements and save files (not the Steam achievements, obviously) and start over from the beginning. This is my go-to game if I need something to busy myself with while I'm watching TV or a movie, because it takes very little of my attention, but is still fun.

17448501.review:
Hello there, you shiny little gem! What do we have here? Our age old, classic card game that we practically grew up with since Windows 3.0 - or as your grandmother's generic hobby - combined with a pretty fairytale and collectibles? I'm in!

The scene opens up to the realm of fairies, threatened by an unspeakable conspiracy. A dark, evil force that we fail to identify enslaves the inhabitants of the realm for its own dark purposes. A kindly old wizard approaches, and declares us as the only possible candidate to save fairies from their torment... with our solitaire skills? (I owe this joke to my friend [url=http://steamcommunity.com/profiles/76561198036498823/recommended/38600/] Solanum Nigrum[/url]. It was originaly in his review, but I couldn't bear myself not to include it, due to the joke being perfectly definitive.) Yes, it is solitaire. Yes, it has a story... and the story actually ends with a huge cliffhanger, so you'll be anticipating for Faerie Solitaire 2 before you know.

Aside from your usual solitaire gameplay, Faerie Solitaire contains some surprises. You earn cash as you progress through various levels of the story - or in any casual game - to obtain upgrades for your gameplay. The gameplay also sets some goals for you in each level, that raises the stakes a bit more, either with time limits or a certain number of cards that you have to make a combo with. You are also entitled to collect some magical eggs that will hatch into various magical beasts. These beasties gain experience as you play and they may be raised into adulthood for their own achievement set.

All in all, it is a good game for a low price that you can pick to pass some mindless time, with interesting features. I also gotta mention that the art is surprisingly beautiful for a casual game. I adored the profile backgrounds and emoticons! I know, I know, it is girly... But I am a girl anyhow. So I am entitled to my fairies, damn it!

Please also check out Lady Storyteller's Curator page [url=http://steamcommunity.com/groups/ladystoryteller#curation]here[/url] - follow for regular updates on reviews for other games!

17368033.review:
Faerie Solitaire is nothing more than what promises to be: a solitaire card game. The game itself, though, is wrapped up in a nice setting with beautiful drawings, pleasant music and sound effects, and a sort of story (don't expect to get hooked on it, though: it's nothing spectacular). The adventure mode presents you with objectives that you need to achieve in order to progress (all related to your solitaire games).

In order to keep you interested, there are also collectable eggs dropped randomly (as far as I can tell) while you play, that you can hatch and evolve into creatures. I think that this is a sort of missed opportunity, because in fact those eggs and creatures have no effects whatsoever on the game play. It would have been nice to get something out of them! On the other hand, the gold that you collect by playing can be used to buy upgrades that will make it easier to reach the objectives of the various levels.

All in all, I recommend this game, as each of its levels is a nice way to spend 15, 20 minutes while you are waiting for something like your meal to be ready, or just before going to bed.

Disclaimer: I received a code for this game from the dev a few years back through a giveaway. 

Faerie Solitaire is a great, "improved" solitaire game. I usually play between rounds of other games, but it's also easy to get sucked in for a few hours in the pleasing ambient music. There is a light story inbetween rounds, but I was too busy clicking through so I could get to the next round. Achievements are there to add another level of progression, most of which you'll earn through regular gameplay, and trading cards for bonus collecting.
The game is not without its flaws however. I could only play this in bursts because it does get repetitive. The game content feels a bit light, with the only mode in addition to Adventure is Challenge. The pet progressions feels worthless, since they don't do anything once you evolve them. 
Overall, pick it up on sale for sure, pick it up at the full price if you want a fun solitaire-inspired game.

17086081.review:
Best .49 I ever spent.

It's a solitaire card game.  If you're expecting something more, you're looking at the wrong game.  If you're expecting just that - a solitaire card game - you are going to be pleasantly surprised.

- Gameplay is simple and easy to learn.  Each game takes 1-2 minutes, each level has 9 games and a level-specific goal to achieve.  The goals are easy to achieve, but perfection is not.

- The adventure mode has a story which is cute but fairly generic.  It's a card game, after all.  Still, I enjoyed it.  The voice acting was even decent.

- The resources and pet gathering was fun.  It doesn't affect the outcome of the game in any way but if you enjoy collecting pets/achievements, you'll find some entertainment in it.

All in all, it's a simple but smooth card game that can be played by kids or adults and can be fairly addicting.  It's likely worth the 10 bucks it costs normally but if you can catch it for .49, even better.   Then you can buy it for your friends, too, and feel better about your own addiction.

Disclaimer: I purchased this game using my own funds, and I do not write a review on a game that I have not paid for myself, because I believe they should be fair and unbiased. I don't believe you can get that unless you invest your own funds and support developers, and provide a personal sense of "value".

This has got to be one of the more enjoyable solitaire card games on the market. I have put over 52 hours into this addicting game. It has a fun background story (which does not interfere with the game play, but merely keeps you involved to continue on your journey), relaxing music, and simple mechanics with fun powerups to assist you along the way. A good value at its current asking price of $10, but I think as a casual game, I would wait for it to be on sale for around $5. It has achievements, trading cards, and is guaranteed to waste a LOT of your time if you are a fan of Faeries whatsoever. 

There are quickplay levels and extra hard challenge levels if you finish or need a break from the Adventure campaign.

If you have this in your library and haven't tried it out yet, you're missing out on a gem.
I read a review once that downvoted this because of no multiplayer option ... This is "Solitaire" ... Enough said LOL.

I wanted to add an edit into this:
If you are an achievement hunter, be forewarned that you have to collect a lot of materials and eggs while you play. This, of course, is governed by random odds. You may have to play quite a bit more to collect all the items you need, and several speculations and theories are presented in the forums.

A report on the randomness: After this review, and having put an extra ten hours here and there into this fun game, I am *still* working on the last two achievements.

Good hunting! :)

16297253.review:
Faerie Solitaire is not your stereotypical solitaire game. Rather than having seven distinct piles of cards which you are trying to put in order, you are instead trying to clear the board. This is done by discarding cards from the table which are within one of the top card in the discard pile. To further spice this up there are special rules and conditions. Most of these involve locking some of the cards until you empty another row or play a specific card.

The game includes an element of collecting and leveling as well. You receive gold, resources, and eggs while you play. Gold is the only thing which has a direct effect on game play as it allows you to buy various bonuses, like undos, to make the game a little easier. The eggs and resources are simply fluff which add to the story.

Yes, I said story. 

This game is driven by a relatively simple story line. You are trying to save the faeries! They use this to justify the different levels, objectives, and added complexity. Each level consists of several chances to meet some objective like combo length, gold earned, or achieving a perfect game within a specified amount of time.

The episodic nature led me to keep playing until well past when I should go to sleep. I found myself wanting to finish a level, or see what the next challenge was, or just finish leveling up my pet...

Overall the game is a satisfying solitaire experience.

15806133.review:
[b]tl;dr -> Was itching for a dirt-cheap impulse buy and happened upon this super simple game and decided to give it a try. 11/10 Solitaire-style gameplay while you raise some dragons.[/b]

I got this game because I was bored and wanted a mindless title to pass the time. I was quite surprised with my gameplay experience.

If you like Solitaire-style card games, faery themes, and raising dragons, then you might enjoy this game. 

The aesthetics are decent - the amount of detail in the cards are very simple. The music and sounds are okay - they do add to the mystical/relaxing vibe emitted by the game - but I quickly muted the music in favor of my own.

Controls are super simple and only involve mouse clicking. There is no tutorial, but tips are always provided when a new element is introduced. The learning curve is mostly non-existent to minimal depending on your knowledge of card games involving a standard deck of 52.

Gameplay consists of you trying to clear a randomized arrangement of cards before running out of cards in your deck (Solitaire-style format). You start by drawing a card, and must click on cards in the play area to interact with your active card. Unlike Solitaire, you can click on cards exactly one value higher or lower than your active card. For example, you start a level and draw a 5 - you can now click on any 4's or 6's in the play area (note that you cannot click on 5's). Chaining combos are important in this game because it will allow you to build up your score meter faster, resulting in more money awarded and a better end score. Your end score fills up a "global" meter that is shown at the end of every level (or hand). After 9 hands, you must have accumulated enough points to free a captured faery. There is always one level objective that lasts for all 9 hands (ex: achieve a 8-chain combo), and completing this will boost your score and money. 

New mechanics are added as you progress through the game to keep things challenging. One includes a vine stack that cannot be accessed until you clear a separate stack of cards that has a flower at the end. Another common one is an ice stack of cards that can only be used if you first click a "fire" card, which is usually located beneath many other cards.

Money is used to buy upgrades in the Faereland in the form of buildings. These upgrades will give you things like an extra undo (you start with only 1 and can get up to a maximum of 3) and a count of how many cards are left in your deck. Sometimes, resources will also drop when you clear a stack of cards - these are used to hatch and evolve your dragons. Yes, dragons.

After playing for a while, you will eventually find a dragon egg (there are a large number of dragon variants). You can hatch them once you've accumulated enough resources (there are 3 kinds). Your dragon will start as a baby, and you can select one active dragon at a time - your active dragon will gain experience whenever you win a hand. Once your dragon receives enough experience, it will evolve and have some lore you can read.

Besides the standard story mode, there is a challenge mode and the ability to replay previous levels. 

Overall, the game plays well for a Solitaire-based game with extra elements to keep it from running dry. If you are interested in this style of gameplay, then give it a try. I try not to mention price if I feel it is unnecessary, but I got this game when it was discounted at 95% ($0.54 CAD) and sincerely think that this is not worth the full price at all ($10.99 CAD). The content is just far too shallow to warrant that price, when countless other titles exist for the same, if not lower price. 

Recommend!

Cheers,
DJSF [url=http://steamcommunity.com/groups/djsfsroguereviews]@DJSF's Rogue Reviews[/url]

14833474.review:
Faerie Solitaire is a noteworthy game that came to my attention after observing numerous acquaintances engaging with it on Steam. Upon procuring it, I experienced a delightful revelation only after a delayed immersion into its offerings. The game effectively marries the concept of solitaire with a few intriguing modifications and incorporates a narrative featuring a child liberating captive faeries while uncovering the underpinnings of the predicament. While the narrative may not delve into profound depths, it maintains one's interest sufficiently and functions as a charming tale in its own right.

The gameplay itself presents a level of simplicity yet deviates from conventional solitaire. Instead of pairing suits until depletion, players aim to formulate combinations with the goal of removing them from the board. The larger the combination, the higher its worth. Progressively, players unlock capabilities including automatic linking of non-combinable cards, additional hold cards available at the player's discretion, and the ability to construct faerie edifices with added perks such as extra undo options.

Each round consists of nine hands, and the entire game comprises around 27 rounds, divided into narrative chapters. Each round comes with specific objectives, such as attaining a particular card total combination or accruing a certain number of points within a specified duration. Progression to subsequent rounds is only permissible upon completion of all goals, thus potentially necessitating round repetition.

In conclusion, Faerie Solitaire struck me as a pleasurable game with a suitable level of challenge yet sufficiently relaxed to accommodate distractions or periods of low motivation. It's highly accessible, suitable for brief gameplay sessions, and an excellent choice when unsure of what to play next. Therefore, I highly recommend Faerie Solitaire with a rating of 9 out of 10.

A rather simple card game to pass the time, Faerie Solitaire is literally as the name implies--a slightly glittered-up version of solitaire. It is something to play should you want to just aimlessly pass the time away. If you have any other games on your list to play, then I suggest playing them first. Don't get me wrong, the game is decent in its own right, but mainly for younger ages, casual gamers, grandparents, or those odd people who actually classify themselves as "gamers" because they play facebook games. It has a few unique factors to it such as pets, achievements, and objectives, which utterly make it seem more and more like it truly does belong on facebook. 

Objectives start out easy and gradually increase with difficulty as you progress through the short and thin plot of the game. If you do not complete an objective on that level then you must start it over completely. This is something that will utterly allow you to waste more time should you so wish. Achievements vary but are relatively simple to grasp and accomplish by just playing the game. Lastly, you can find eggs and other "mystical" items as you progress, and they allow you to hatch them and raise your own pets/creatures over time. There are baby and adult versions of each creature--it evolves when you acquire the appropriate materials and earn enough exp (which you attain by simply putting time into the game I believe). The point of the game is to fill "Faerie Land" with creatures and release trapped Faeries by playing the card games somehow... Overall, I recommend Faerie Solitaire only if you are truly bored or have a younger sibling/child you wish to entertain while babysitting them.
