13980008.review:
Faerie Solitaire is an attempt to wrap a story around a game of solitaire where you attempt to "clear" the play field of all the cards. There are additional aspects like win money to buy upgrades, and collect creature eggs and ingredients to evolve them. However, the difficulty curve is uneven, and the various aspects never integrated into a cohesive experience.

Basic gameplay is solitaire, the kidn where you have a bunch of cards, only some were open (but the unopen ones may be face up so you can plan better). You have the remainder of the deck, and you have ONE open card. The objective to to match your open card with the open card on the deck that's one higher or one lower (color/suit is irrelevant) and attempt the clear the entire board before your deck runs out. You can achieve partial success by removing most of the cards (which fills up the purple power meter), and if you managed to clear the board you get "perfect" hand (and bonus reward)

You will also need achieve up to 3 objectives by end of 9 hands, which consists of a level. Each "stage" is composed of multiple hands, and there are 8 stages overall, resulting in a lot of solitaire play. Some additional complications, such as "frozen" or "thorn-locked" sections and timed goals makes things interesting, but this game is really for people who can play LOT of solitaire... of one kind only. 

The story line and combat is not really integrated into the game itself, much like Puzzle Kingdom or Puzzle Quest. After all, this is solitaire, with no competition except against oneself. So somehow, while the story is fairly compelling, with a twist mid-game, the game doesn't quite "feel" much like going on a quest, but more like uncovering sections of a story book, doing some unrelated stuff to unlock the next chapter. And that really distracts from the game. 

Furthermore, the game's difficulty curve is not even. The powerups that you can buy can affect the game greatly. There are a stage or two where you need to get THREE perfect hands out of nine hands total. That turned out to be VERY very hard without a certain powerup. 

To add some "value" to the game the developers added "pet collecting", as you can find magical ingredients and occasional some magic creature eggs when you clear the board (i.e. get "perfect" hand) and if play with the baby creature enough hands, and have the right ingredients, you can "evolve" the creatures into "adult form". However, there seem to be no relation of the creatures to the story OR the game, so it felt as if it's tacked on to FORCE some completionists to replay the game to get all creatures and/or their adult forms. 

There are some challenge levels not related to the adventure mode, but that's not much fun there. 

As you win each hand you accumulate some monetary winnings that can be used to buy certain powerups, which gives you extra UNDO, peek at the next card in your deck, and so on. Those can be quite expensive but can make your late games easier, esp. the power to "zap" a card off the board. But again, the monetary value isn't integrated into the story much. 

One very annoying aspect is sometimes there are timers, like "fill the purple power bar in 2 minutes", but there is no timer on screen that tells me when my 2 minutes is up!  (And there's an impossible achievement: get a perfect hand in under 1 minute)

All in all, Faerie Solitaire is an indie game that tried to marry a story to soltaire play, but didn't quite succeed, as the various elements sucha s pet, money, and story don't mesh. 

The game ended on a cliffhanger, leaving it to the sequel. Let's hope the sequel is more... integrated than this first attempt. But NOT recommended, unless you REALLY love playing soltaire.

13897568.review:
A largely luck-based game, solitaire is an unusual game to think of for a game where they rate you on how many "perfect" games you can get, but that's exactly what they're doing.  They make it easier, at least in the early levels, but it's still by and large luck, and you'll occasionally get a board start with all the 4s in a row on the bottom, and all the 3s and 5s behind them so that it's flat impossible to play that hand.  Want to reset so you get a hand you can play? Too bad, you have to do a set of 9 hands in a levle, and resetting means losing all your cash and items and starting back from the beginning of the hand, meaning you wasted the last 8 minutes you were playing.  Like real solitaire, it's luck-based, but real solitaire just shrugs and lets you play again.  In Fairie Solitaire, it lets you know you're a failure for something beyond your control... other than just not playing the game.

Of course, even if you are a perfectionist, there's very little reason to want to go back.  There's an award for beating a hand in less than a minute, but a more reasonable pace is about 2 minutes a hand, and there are 9 hands a level, 5 levels a stage, and 8 stages... That is, 6 hours if you never have to repeat things... and you WILL have to repeat things.

Hands and levels are little different from one another.  They do have things like a "thorn patch", which is a line of cards that only opens up when you clear some other line of cards, or an "ice wall", which is a line of cards that only opens up... when you clear some other line of cards.  Basically, it's the same tricks over and over, but with a different icon for it. Get ready to grind, because they couldn't think of anything more to add to solitaire.  (Note that even the positive reviews here say that this game is EXTREMELY repetitive.)  Note that levels basically repeat the same placement patterns and hoops to jump through, just the exact order of cards is different, so expect repeating levels to get VERY old VERY fast.  In a supposedly 6 hour game, some of these people have 20 hours or more...

There's voice acting, but it's tied to the music volume for reasons I can't comprehend, and the music is far, FAR louder than the voice, so you have to crank it down to a whisper so the music doesn't deafen you.

There's a "pet system" but it's really just randomly getting things about 0.01% of the time when you clear a line, and then getting told you are "leveling up" this thing by just doing what you were doing, anyway.  Pets do nothing.  At all.  You can't even see them in the corner of the screen as you play.  They just require you select them to have them invisibly gain XP to invisibly grow up (after you give them resources that are also random drops) so that you check another box off on the way to completion.  Plus, there's a ton of them there, since, of course, if you're going to tack these things on just to extend gameplay, you might as well make them drop rarely, have a ton of them, no player control over what you get, and put out an achievement for it if you Gotta Catch 'Em All.

It's also bizzarely unoptimized, lagging on my computer and using up all the CPU it can get in spite of it being a rock-simple sprite-based game.

Also, if you look at the art and think you might want to play it just because you like fairies or something, keep in mind that they basically don't appear much.  Even the pets are things like robots instead of fairies, at least the ones I got, and most of the time, the fairies are just yellow glowy bits in a jar you get to release for nothing more than a "Thank you :D" at the end of a level.  99% of the game has no fairy onscreen, just cards.  They only appear in a few still images, all of which appear in the screenshot gallery, or between stages.

All told, it looks feels, and plays like the sort of game marketed to older women who don't play anything but casual games, and the amount of quality and effort that went into the game reflects the sort of mentality of someone with only enough skill or dedication to pull off something just barely excusible to ship to a less discriminating customer base if you just have a fairy theme in it.  

I got it for $0.50 on a 95% off sale, which says a lot about the game, and I sold the cards for nearly enough to pay for itself, but it still wasn't all that great an experience...  Definitely only buy on sale when you have enough in your Steam Wallet to not even notice the money spent, if at all...

13895833.review:
I didn't like the story, which didn't really feel like part of the game, but otherwise the game is quite nice. Regular solitaire can be fairly monotonous, so the challenges set in this game bring some variety. I played the adventure mode through and it really is nicer to play in quickplay or challenges as you don't need to listen to the story anymore. Also, the pets aren't any use, except for getting 100% achievements, if you're a completionist.

I play the game in normal mode, which sometimes feels a bit too easy. There are also Master and Impossible modes for those who want to up the difficulty. Maybe I should also mention that I got the game from Steam sale and only paid 0.49€. I wouldn't pay full price for this.

13726553.review:
Hey everyone and this is my review about the game!

This is a card game.


[h1]Interface/Menu/Settings[/h1]

The game is zoomed in when playing on fullscreen mode.
You can play the game windowed mode.
There are no resolution sizes available.
There is a master volume slidebar available.
There is an ambience volume slidebar available.
There is a sound effect slidebar available.
There is a difficulty settings.

[h1]About the game.[/h1]

This is a simple card game. You have to make a small chain of cards that are +1 or -1. So let's say you have a number 5 as a card. You will have to find and match a card that is 4 or 6. Doing alot of these will give you combo. There are objectives in the game and those are dependant on which difficulty you are playing. Higher difficulty means harder objectives. You are able to get gold which you could spend on buildings in the faerie land. Buildings are pretty expensive but they could make things a bit easier for you.

There is a small tutorial available.
You are able to skip cutscenes.
There is voiced over.
Calm game.
Buildings to make things easier.

[h1]Other things.[/h1]

None.

-------------------

I Give this game a 5/10

13673007.review:
Have you ever spent hours on a Windows PC playing Hearts, Solitaire, Spider Solitaire, Freecell, or any of those other card games?  Expect to spend a lot of time with this title!  Unlike the other standard Windows offerings, this game includes rpg elements such as a type of in-game currency (no microtransactions here though!) where you can purchase various upgrades, and a "pet" system that lets you change the background of the cards in your deck.

Now there's an alleged story element as well, demonstrating itself as nothing more than powerpoint slides with some voiceover narration.  It would work well on its own as a children's fable, but as it stands it is simply jarring and distracts one from the experience, and gets in the way of the card game.  The story element might count as a visual novel, if one was willing to disrespect the vast genre of visual novels by including this game's "story" in its ranks.

The game itself is great, and that aspect alone is worth several bucks.  Be warned that the cutscenes are far less engaging than usual, though!

Who doesn't like to wind down with a quiet solo card game after a hard day fo hacking and slashing zombie flesh with a party of 5 or 6 rude, insulting strangers, and then maybe playing a video game later? (Did you see what I did there?)

This game was a very pleasant surprise. It's just solitaire, but it's not [i]just[/i] solitaire. It's a very attractive and well-implemented game of solitaire with interesting twists and variations, and there's some extra stuff going on too. While playing, you find eggs that you can hatch, and then the hatchlings will evolve with the aid of "resources" you uncover in the card games. You also win play-money that you can spend on infrastructure that will give you minor game perks or help speed your hatchery along.

Or, you can just play solitaire and ignore your pets, as I do the adventure story that appears in snippets as you win sets of games.

All in all, a very good game.

There are some super moves (which you can purchase and some that unlock) thrown on top of the standard solitaire rules, like having to use a fire spell power up to melt an ice card that is otherwise blocking your stack of cards.  I liked these touches and it helped to keep me at the game when a standard solitaire rule set would have bored me.  Graphically it’s sparse but has a nice fantasy theme, music never bothered me and the story is told in story book cut scenes which I found charming.  If you like fantasy settings and solitaire than this is the game for you.

[b]PROS:[/b]
+ interesting story for a Solitaire game
+ nice UI
+ classic Solitaire experience
+ relaxing

[b]CONS:[/b]
- can get boring after a longer while of playing
- repetitive gameplay

[b]Comment:[/b]
The first 25 hours in this game have been fun. It's the concept of Solitaire combined with a story campaign. Poured into the mix are also RPG elements, challenges and some achievements. While not astounding this game is good. However I gave a point less for the tedious egg gathering which works in a really funky way. As you see above I have played about 68 hours in total, that's becuse of the totally random egg appearance combined with a bad way of generating them. I would still recommend it as it is relaxing and fun for the most part.

12355904.review:
I...  guess I recommend this.  I mean, if you like solitaire, this is a solitaire game, and it plays well.  It's similar to tripeaks solitaire.  In between the solitaire you have some story bits in the form of text during loading screens, and them some sortof cut scenes, which isn't terrible and can be skipped, and maybe has some suspense to it if you don't guess what's going on.  You're some kid tasked with chasing after the fairies to save them from something evil, or something like that.  And you play a lot of solitaire to save them, because it is pretty apparent you have the fighting skills of Atreyu from The Neverending Story when he killed the wolf simply by holding the sword the right way as he cowered when it pounced.

I played this for about 27 hours and got all but two achievements.  Then I quit, because it's a painful grind to get all the eggs to randomly drop.  Then I came back after a couple months and my save game is deleted.  I looked online and this is a common issue, and the game does not and according to the devs will not support Steam's cloud sync.  Better find and back up your save game regularly.  Maybe even before finishing each level, because some of the tasks get really annoying when you play ten rounds to find that you didn't win enough of them, so start over.

So bottom line, it's cheap, tho not as cheap as that Klondike or Spider solitaire built into your Windows install.  You might see where the story is going long before they reveal it.  You may rage quit when you play fifty games in a row without an egg drop.  Your save game may just magically cease to exist.  Your friends may tease you for playing a game with "Faerie" in the title.  But if you enjoy passing the time playing card games, these other issues don't matter.

11889076.review:
[b]June 4, 2015[/b]
I got this game for 95% off, expecting a crappy game but cards to turn a profit. I was surprisingly impressed.

Faerie Solitaire is surprisingly solid and engaging, easy to play and still satisfying with crisp sounds and a nice style. Gameplay is random but still functional at the start, with new mechanics added gradually to alleviate the problems of random card draws. In a few hours, you can 100% any level by pure skill and planning. The progression system is solid, although collecting all the eggs is too random. The only bug that stands out is the first card not counting for Aura Ring if unused. It can be worked around by drawing the next card and using Undo, but it's something that should've been noted and fixed.

It is basically a free game that would be played online or on mobile, but it is polished and engaging enough to be worthwhile. I probably have 30 hours that haven't shown up due to playing offline. Offline play is one strength I would also consider; achievements unlocked offline will pop on Steam when you check the in-game achievements while online. Keeping this in mind, you can save the last Faerie Land purchase or Challenge stage to complete online, hitting all the offline achievements without backtracking.

There is a fair amount to enjoy in this game, but it will get old after some time. But 40 hours of enjoyable gameplay is worth a purchase for those interested. I'd recommend the game at 75% off or better for most players.

I got a 90% off coupon to get this game when I completed a badge, and I thought “What the heck, solitaire is fun sometimes.” Now, I have almost twenty hours on record, and I don’t plan on stopping any time soon. If you see this game on sale and you like card style games even a little bit, it’s worth it to pick it up. 
The gameplay is simple enough. You are dealt a board and you have to make chains from your foundation card. In order words, say your card is an eight. You can place a nine or seven from the board onto your foundation, and you can go up or down. As you remove cards from the board, other cards get revealed. It’s simple enough until they start throwing ice cards at you that have to be “unfrozen” with a fire card, or thorns that you have to untangle by uncovering all the cards on a rose. Then, as you remove cards from the board you might suddenly come across an egg. You can hatch your eggs for little pets. Do these pets do anything? Nope! But I have a baby unicorn!
So yeah, this game is highly addictive. Find the game too easy? Try the challenge mode and bang your head against the keyboard. Find the game too tough? Try quickplay or adventure mode. You can also spend in-game currency to unlock “talents” that help make the game easier like the ability to preview the next card in your deck, or the ability to know how many cards are remaining in your deck. 
So, to wrap it up, I understand that ten dollars is a lot to spend on a solitaire game, but honestly It’s a great game and definitely worth it to pick it up on sale. The only thing that might turn people off is the “fairy” package the surrounds the play style. Yes, it’s a bit feminine but honestly it’s not going to stop your enjoyment in any way. (Baby unicorn!)

11143120.review:
What to say about Faerie Solitaire? I saw a bunch of my Steam friends playing this and went ahead an bought it a while back, but didnt really crack into it until recently. It was a very pleasant surprise. It's solitaire with a few twists and a little story about a kid who finds faeries in captivity and frees them while seeking out the reason all of this is happening. Nothing too deep about the story, but it does hold your interest well enough, and is a nice fable on its own. 
The gameplay itself is simple enough...it is not exactly solitaire, in that rather than match suits until you run out of cards, you are instead trying to build combos to take off the board using your held cards as the base card for said combos. The bigger the combo, the more it is worth. Additionally, you unlock powers such as being able to automatically link a card that would not normally combo, receive extra hold cards to use when you see fit, and build faerie structures that add benefits such as extra undo-s (which you can use to go back one move if you realize you made a mistake), the ability to look at the next card in your deck, and so on.
Each round is made up of nine hands, and there were something like 27 rounds total, broken up into story chapters (each chapter is 3 rounds). Each round has a set of goals, which might include a certain card total combo being reached (8, 10, 12, even 15 in some rounds), acquire a certain amount of points, and fill your charge meter within a certain amount of time. You cant move forward until you meet all the goals, so you may end up repeating a round from time to time.

Anyway, I found this to be a pleasant game with a reasonable amount of challenge, but still something you can do while distracted or feeling particularly unmotivated to do much of anything. I guess what I am saying is it is completely accessible to anybody, can be played in small snippets, and easily fills the gaming void when you aren't sure what else you want to play.

9 out of 10

11140215.review:
If there was a 'Maybe' option for recommendation, I would select that. The game is basically a variant on Solitaire where you have one deck you draw from to grab cards from the playing field to clear the playing field. The playing field has differing sized stacks that may sometimes overlap, as well as quirky 'seals' where a stack is locked until a requirement is met (clearing a specific card or clearing a specific stack). 

There are stages, which are broken down into levels, and each level has 9 hands. Each level has a number of objectives that must be completed by the last hand or you fail and must restart the level. It's a pretty simple game and has a friendly atmosphere that is very kid friendly. 

I have one complaint about the game though, and as anyone looking through the forums will see it is the same gripe as everyone else; pet eggs and hatching. It is completely luck and time based to acquire the final two achievements, and many people have spent countless hours grinding these out. And it is not as if the pets actually do anything or serve any purpose other than lore and cuteness. The pets are completely pointless and are a huge time sink. I am VERY lucky to have gotten all but one egg (at the time of writing this) in 27 hours of gameplay (idle time spent in my shop when I have nothing to do while watching episodes of Futurama).  

BUT aside from that, the game is solid, visually appealing, has a story (which I skipped entirely so no idea how good it is), and the music is pleasing (up until the 20th hour or so). Do I recommend? Maybe. But because I have only two options, I will say 'Yes'.

11120146.review:
A decently challenging solitare game with a nice bunch of achievments to go for. Some are really easy and others take a lot of planning and saving of spare cards to get (20 card combo? Have fun saving up a bunch of cards for that one!)

Adding in a pet system is useful too. Play card games until you get enough to hatch and evolve them. Their abilities are very helpful in completing the game.

I found it nice that this game doesn't force you to keep replaying a round over and over and trying to use every card possible. It's just more of "you did the best you could and that's what counts" and moves you on. You never have a time you won't get all the EXP needed to complete a chapter.

The story seems kind of bland to me sadly. It's fairies and I like faires as much as princesses and the such but the story just seems to kind of draw on to me and given how many chapters there are, you're going to be sitting here for a long time completing the game, not to mention trying to save up to buy all the stuff in the villiage that will help you complete the game quicker and help save your bacon on an occassion or two.

If you enjoy card games with fantasy and stories weaved into them, you'll most likely enjoy this one. Bought this game for $0.99 with a coupon so if you can, would recommend trying to get a coupon for this game then buying it. Achievments, steam cards, and all, this game is alright and fun.

It's Solitaire. Not much to say about solitaire. If you have time to kill or are bored, pick this game up and wonder afterwards where your afternoon went.  It is addictive, I find myself playing this really late into the night to the point where normal reaction time is dulled because you're already asleep on the inside, but your eyes stay fixated on the monitor.

The story was not bad, predictable at best, but not many are here for the story. I did enjoy getting audio snippets of plot after every nine levels and a storyboard cut scene after every stage.  It set's up a lot of spoken audio and the voice acting wasn't bad, I've heard worse in a game before.

10993083.review:
I'm up to 56 games following the Summer Sale, and honestly, Faerie Solitaire may be my greatest gain following the money sink.

The sounds of this game set the mood. It's relaxed, with lute/harp/whatever-esque strums used as you move through menus. You have nature sounds in the background as you play through the game, and you get nice musical overtures when you complete a stage.

The game is pretty-- not ground-breaking graphics or anything, but everything about it looks nice. It's a card game and it understands that. It never tries to be overly fabulous. It's two-dimensional, it's got good artwork, and things have auras and sparkles and glows. Don't let that last bit throw you off-- it's subtle enough that it won't annoy you.

You'll find eggs and materials and stuff like that to grow baby pets into badass not-baby pets. You get dragons and all that good stuff. You also unlock power-ups and improvements to your game; stuff like improved hatching speeds, seeing how many cards you have left in your deck, and cheat codes where you can see what's the next card in the stack.

But the thing that matters the most is that the game is just fucking fun. It's casual and it accepts that. It's the game you play when you're tired but can't sleep, when you don't want to think too hard, or you're in the middle of searching for a match on LoL or whatever you play and it's taking a very long time. The game does what it does well, and it doesn't try to be your favorite game, but it accidentally comes close anyway.

10784259.review:
Faerie Solitaire shouldn't be engrossing. It shouldn't be addictive. The artwork is beautiful and the sound effects are pretty nice, but the UI is just north of mediocre, in that it's pretty lo-fi (even for 2010) and the number of different fonts used on a single screen is kind of distracting. There are things that are gimmicky and don't really make sense: the hatching and evolution of pets that do nothing, for example. The writing could use an editor and the voice-acting is…meh. The story is repetitive (once again, I again, yet again), to the extent that I eventually just started skipping the narrative (kudos to Subsoap for allowing this).

Sounds pretty bad, right? And yet, I played through to the rolling end credits in a single sitting, then returned to try for some of the more difficult achievements. Faerie Solitaire is much more than the sum of its parts. It's relaxing and entertaining, and it kept me interested with frequent pet discoveries (I like unlocking things). The only gameplay complaint I have is that, in a casual, play-at-your-own-pace game like this, I really don't like the introduction of timers. Some of the objectives require you to finish within a certain amount of time, and I'm just not a fan of time-based challenges.

I really enjoyed this game. I put about 20 hours into it, which works out to 50¢ an hour at its regular price. Mostly because the presentation is outdated, it's a little difficult to recommend Faerie Solitaire at full price when Steam has so many quality titles on offer for a fraction of the price, but I still think it's worth it, and I'm very interested to see what they've learned and improved in FaeVerse Solitaire.

10511226.review:
A great Solitare game. There's upgrades to buy, and many pets to collect and grow. Collecting all the pets can be a chore though, since the eggs they hatch from are randomly spawned from game to game, so sometimes you can go dozens of games without seeing an egg. Well, towards the end of the pet collecting anyway. At the beginning you get them at a decent rate, but around the halfway mark it starts to slow down. Also, it takes 'time' to hatch and then mature. Each card you click will tick down it's 'hatching' and/or 'growing timer, so it can take a while.

However, the pet feature is completely optional. This is the kinda game people buy when they either want a coffee break game, or they're a huge fan of solitaire games. Either way, you'll be playing this game a lot normally and the pet feature is a nice thing to do on the side, which for long term players is the only thing left on the side.

There's an upgrade system which will make playing more convieniet, however it doesn't take too long to max those out and afterwards the only thing left is the pet feature and solitaire... which is great too.

Overall, this is just a great game and the devs are great people. Back when this game was first released, the devs were generous enough to host many giveaways in various communities, giving away quite a few copies, which is how I got mine.

As for the current price point, I feel $10 is a good price considering that this game has given me more hours than an uncomfortable number of AAA.

I love this game!

What makes Faerie Solitaire such an enjoyable ride is its ability to have this long lasting appeal. You can play this for a long time due to its simple and addictive nature.

In adventure mode, you collect money and materials to use for upgrades. As if solitaire wasn't addictive already, the great minds at Subsoap decided to add RPG elements to it and pets, yes, I said pets!

Great casual fun to unwind with.

9995095.review:
Faerie Solitaire is an average Solitaire game and lacking in the "neat things we added that make it different" department. There's a story mode that throw objectives like "create a 5 combo" or "clear a stage in less than a minute" or "get x number of perfect clears" at you and you can't progress until you clear all of the objectives and pass/fail all 9 stages. It gets incredibly repetitive. Between stages you get some exposition that tells you about the backstory and why you're playing Solitaire to rescue fairies and stuff but it has absolutely no effect on the gameplay and it is there just to look nice. 

Sometimes when you clear cards you find either materials or a creature egg that you can hatch and equip. After you've equipped the pet for long enough time you can evolve it, provided that you've obtained enough of the aforementioned materials. There are over 30 pets to collect and evolve and not a single one of the pets do a damn thing for the game overall. They're just there to look nice and provide fake replay value. 

Since this is a card game there has to be some degree of randomness to it. The objectives for each stage are fixed, but everything else is random. Whether you get eggs or materials behind cards is random. Whether your pet evolves or not is probably random too. The game tells you that it evolves after you get enough EXP but that's just as good as saying "your pet will randomly evolve as you play." Clearing a stage is pretty much random too. Which is great for the challenge modes where you often have to win at least 3+ times to pass that challenge mode. I spent 5 hours trying to clear Stone Temple and you need 6 perfects to pass it, and the most I ever got was 5. Completely arbitrary and random. Casual, sure, but to the point of frustration.

9988821.review: A variety of different solitaire card games wrapped in a faerie story binding. If you like computerised solitaire, it's well worth the purchase. If you don't, it isn't. It's that simple.

9600492.review:
Short of it: I loved this game - right up until the cliffhanger ending and trying to find the last two eggs.  I got this game for $1 and had a lot of fun with it, but the ending and the egg drop rate left me not with warm fuzzy feelings but feelings leaning more toward annoyance and anger.  Part 2 has become a huge project with 15 parts and last I checked part 4 wasn't even done.  A remastered version of the original is in the works to fix the egg drop problem, but it means starting the game over.

Long of it: I enjoy solitaire games anyway, but thought the fairy theme was really fun.  I was enjoying the story and the sense that something wasn't quite right and I really wanted to know what happened next.  I felt like I was finding pets on pace to maybe unlock them all by the time I finished story mode.  I really liked that the pets had baby and adult forms, but I felt like the evolving process was too slow.  Then I got to the end of the game and after my initial shock upon realizing that really was the ending, I told myself surely they must have released the second part by now since this game is over three years old.  After some research, I discover that not only have they not released part two, they have turned it into this huge project of 15 parts and they haven't even completed part 4.  However, the really frustrating thing is trying to get the last two pet eggs.  After you clear all the cards in a stack there is a chance that a material will drop (used to evolve your pets), nothing will drop, or an egg will drop.  Then IF it is an egg drop, it is a random drop of an egg from any level and if you already have all the eggs in that level you get no drop.  I'm not big on the math but that means your odds of dropping that last egg or two are ridiculously low.  Check out the forums and read the many frustrated posts of people who have spent 100+ hours on this game and still have not found the last eggs.  The developers have responded and said that instead of patching the game, they will be releasing a remastered version that addresses this issue and removes the randomness from the drops after so long.  However, that was announced in 2012 and whenever it is released it means starting over. 
I've put 16 hours into this game and I still have 9 pets to evolve and 2 to find. Like I said, I really enjoyed the story and I like the idea of the pets, but I find the replayability of this game to be really low - aside from the forced replayability of trying to find the last two pet eggs and evolve the pets. 

I absolutely recommend this game if you can find it for $1 like I did, if not unlocking all the achievements is ok with you, and if you go in eyes wide open that the ending is a cliffhanger.

Edit - Since writing this review, the developer has decided to release a game called FaeVerse Alchemy which is in early access (still in development).  I have no idea why they would choose to push this in front of Faerie Solitaire 2 (which they agree is overdue).  I understand them pushing it in front of the remaster of the original Faerie Solitaire because they have promised the remastered version as a free update.  Still it's lame.

9597761.review:
This really takes basic solitaire above and beyond.

I love all the layouts and different goals to beat certain ones, like ice walls or rose vines. I also love the cute, fairy graphics, much nicer on the eyes than plain old cards. The added pet element adds fun as well, reminding me somewhat of pokemon. You can find eggs under certain cards, hatch them, raise them and find certain gems to help them evolve.

There are also certain bonuses you can save up funds to buy, like extra undos and power ups that work from cards you can't use. I also liked the journey/adventure part of this.

Each level has 9 levels you have to beat, and each level of nine has certain goals. Like completing X amoung perfectly, or earning X amount of $ or getting X amound of combos in a row.

I really liked all these aspects as it made a whole new game out of solitaire, adding new challenges and making the replayability high and fun! Highly recommended to all!

9562033.review:
Steam really needs an "in-between" rating.  Overall it’s a fun modification of solitaire and a somewhat addictive casual time killer.  There's in-game money (not real money with microtransactions) you can earn to buy items that can effect gameplay in your favor, and there are various challenges in each level, plus a whole extra level of multiple challenges.  

However, it does have several negative points that make it not worth $10.  Buy it on sale or find one of the many 90% off coupons floating around Steam.

Be prepared for the sub-par graphics.  After about 2000 no game developer would consider making a game with a highest possible resolution of 800x600.  And yet Subsoap did - in 2010.  Why?  You either play in tiny windowed mode or you play full screen with stretchy and sometimes blocky graphics.

[b]False or misleading claims:[/b]

“40 Unique Fantasy Locations to Explore” and "Adventure Mode: Explore the world of Avalon" – Explore is an extremely incorrect and misleading verb.  You aren’t exploring anything – only going from one background plate to another.
“Earn achievements as you play - 30 To Collect In All” – Two of them are apparently bugged and either unobtainable or require 50+ game hours.

“Fantasy Story Complete with 8 Hand Painted Cutscenes” – the story reads like slash fanfiction written by a 13-year old girl and it’s voiced by a guy who sounds like he’s doing a parody of Keanu Reeves in Dracula.

9185171.review:
I got this game for myself and my wife during one of Subsoap's giveaways on reddit. We were both surprised to find the game was pretty fun.

It's a fairly simple card card game where you attempt to take cards from a layout and place them on your deck. You can only place cards that immediately precede or follow the face up card on the top of your deck. There are a number of bonuses and goals, plus a narrated story between hands, that keep the game lively and interesting.

One drawback is the game's fixed resolution. Every time I play, I have to adjust my monitor's aspect ratio to make the game's screen large enough to see properly. If it weren't for that, I'd probably play it more often. As it is, I've put in about 11 hours on it and it's only now starting to wear a little thin.

It's a fun time-waster that'd be worth maybe $5.

9007139.review:
Solitaire may not be a terribly entertaining game, but it does scratch a certain itch in a calming, addictive way. It's pure escapism, a low-calorie nutritionless fluff for the reptilian parts of the brain to feast upon. Faerie Solitaire takes this base and adds a variety of new hooks to keep you going, such as adorable pets to raise, a village to upgrade with hard-earned fae bucks, and a whole lot of imprisoned faeries for your generic male hero to rescue. On top of that, the pace is strangely merciless; you jump from one stage to the next without getting a chance to spend your new gold and resources on upgrades. To do so requires shamefully quitting mid-hand, and to actually quit the game itself requires a few more steps of legwork and runs you past the Challenge Mode gift shop before letting you out.

The gameplay itself is perhaps a few degrees less brainless than that of actual Solitaire, but it's still a game that mostly plays itself and is almost entirely at the mercy of the way the deck was initially dealt. On the easiest difficulty setting, this doesn't matter; it would take phenomenally bad luck not to meet the meager victory requirements for each stage. On the most difficult, you're more likely to get struck by lightning than to win without grinding endlessly for the consumable items that break the game entirely. Regardless of difficulty, the gameplay is the same, a repetitive series of clicks that gives you just enough of a reward feed to make you feel accomplished. Don't bother with this one; the spell breaks early and if you really need an endlessly addictive time-sink, there are much better perfectly free ones.

8930182.review:
[b][u]Grade[/u]:[/b] 94/100
[b][u]Difficulty[/u]:[/b] Some of the challenge modes can be difficult, but even the later levels of the game are feasible with a little practice or luck. Overall, I'd say easy-to-moderate.
[b][u]Pros[/u]:[/b] A storyline twist to an otherwise straightforward game, with added collectibles and a handful of goals to strive for. The music is alright in most of it, some places it's better to mute it. Relaxing gameplay, for the most part.
[b][u]Cons[/u]:[/b] It takes forever to get some of the collectibles. The storyline is actually quite irritating. There is a second game coming out at some point (the story in this game ends on a cliffhanger), so hopefully they improve upon it.
[b][u]Replayable[/u]:[/b] Yes. Both for relaxing while playing something other than the solitaire that came with your operating system, and also for getting the rest of your collectibles or beating the challenge levels.

8871093.review:
Faerie solitaire is the type of game I find anger-inducing, but only because I have no clue why I enjoy it so much.

It's true, the asking price of 10$ is a little steep, and the storyline is loosely tied in, and unless you change the difficulty from 'normal', you could have played through this game in kindergarten. All of that is true. This is by no means a 9/10 game, or even an 8/10.

Yet when I play this game, I have this childlike sense of wonder and fun that surrounds me like an aura. Is it the fantastically made music? Is it the charming whimsical graphics? Or is it just because the game is mindless fun?

It's true, this game is 'casual.' And frankly, the only way to enjoy this game is if you shut off your brain's 'Ebert' mode. If you look at this game too critically, it's not good. But the number one thing I look for in a game is to have a good time. With certain exceptions, that's exactly what games want to bring consumers. And you know what? I had a fantastic time playing this game from start to finish.

It's not perfect, and if you're going to get it I suggest waiting for a discount, but it's great fun. Recommended.

8614507.review: Faerie Solitaire is a casual card game that is a variaton on Solitaire, with a layout similar to Free Cell.  You match up cards in ascending and descending values, trying to pull all of the cards on the board in to the discard deck.  The entire board doesn't need to be cleared to win.  However, if all of the cards from the board, you win prizes that can be used to hatch eggs and raise fantasy creatures.  The fantasy creatures are completely non-interactive, and are displayed like museum pieces.  Each set of hands completed advances the fairy tale storyline, which is pretty bland.  The problem with the story is it is released in such small pieces that it is sometimes hard to follow.  The story is boring, but thankfully the card game itself isn't so bad.  Overall, the game is really easy, and doesn't take too much thinking.  A good distraction if you have some time to waste.

Faerie solitaire is just a game, it's not jaw dropping amazing, but it IS fun, the simple kind of fun that is good for burning the hours away till you have to do something productive without getting yourself invested in something major. So go buy it you have the money to spend, it's fun, it's simple, and it's not going to eat your soul.

8528609.review:
Faerie Solitaire falls under the category of games that you will either really enjoy or absolutely hate. It plays very much like a Popcap game (Peggle, Insaniquarium, etc.) in that the gameplay is single click, very basic strategy level gameplay. You build sequences of cards together with some minor strategy thrown in, but don't expect much in the way of challenge. Like Popcap games, someone on the development team wasted their time creating a useless story. Like the Popcap games, the story doesn't do anything for the gameplay and might as well not exist. It's a nice casual game, the best recommendation I can give is to go to Youtube, watch a bit of gameplay footage, and if it seems like something you might like, pick it up.

As a final note, the game is not worth 10 dollars, highly recommend waiting until you can find this on sale unless you get really interested. I picked it up in a humble bundle and found it to be a nice surprise at that price, cannot recommend at all for 10 bucks.

8496957.review:
Faerie Solitaire is an excellent card game.  It is played much like the traditional game TriPeaks but with the added excitement of a story line.  The other big difference between TriPeaks and Faerie Solitaire is that Faerie Solitaire has different card layouts for each hand and level.  as the player progresses through the game there are different kinds of challenge cards that require special cards to be used before other cards are revealed.  This adds a fun challenge to the upper levels.  In addition to the clearing of the cards, to progress though the story line the player must also meet certain  goals such as, get an 8 card streak and earn $2000, these goals must be met during one or more hands in a level to release the faerie at the end of the level.  There are also fun upgrades and pets you can earn and level up.


This is also an excellent starter game for Steam, a player new to Steam is quickly introduced to achievements and playing cards.

8433772.review:
Game: Faerie Solitaire
Genre: Puzzle
Developer: Subsoap
System: Steam (PC)
Total Score: 76/100
Value Score: 7.6/10

• Story: 7/10
o Basically a story involving a character who goes on a journey in a mysterious world. The game continues the storyline as you go through the levels in a artistic view of the surrounding world of the game.

• Characters: 5/10
o Basically there are a few characters, your character whose identity isnt even known or a focal point, a bunch of faeries who play different roles and make an appearance in the storyline and your pets you can collect and grow.

• GamePlay: 8/10
o Basically the game is like Solitaire except you can do all sorts of tricks and be encountering certain obstacles which can be destroyed by attempting certain combos. Each level and stage has a unique goal or requirement such as completing a level in a amount of time, having a certain number of combos or making enough money. At the end of each stage you gain a bit of money from you gained during gameplay and as a extra bonus. You can use these extra amounts of money to purchase different abilities and locations - along with the money you also receive or find items during the gameplay which you can use to feed your pet and thus make them stronger.

• Graphics: 7/10
o The game has a unique art style but pretty much any PC should be able to run this game. Very basic visual design more like a art book. The storyline is depicted through the fancy artwork and the animations within the gameplay and the menus are well done.

• Sound: 8/10
o The sound effects are like what you would expect in a fairy tale type of setting of a story. The usual magical incantation sound effects and etc. The sounds are actually well done.

• Music: 7/10
o For each level there's a different track used which plays a soothing calm song representing the stage's environment. The game's menu music is well done, nothing special with the entire OST but it is a nice departure from what you would hear from the usual games as this game's OST fits well with its casual feel.

• Length: 8/10
o There are several levels and stages with about over 8 chapters with several stages. Going through them and playing the game of solitaire may take you a while - each play should take you about anywhere between 5-10 minutes depending on the number of cards and obstacles.

• Replay Value: 9/10
o Although there are specific obstacles in each stage the number of cards and which cards are stacked are always different so each time you play any level in any stage it is always different. Along with that even after you finish the game's main storyline there may be some extra items you can purchase or train more pets which will add a few more hours overall to your game time.

• Player Value: 7/10
o If you are looking for a casual game that doesnt require a lot of PC power - something to get your time by and something that is actually quite simple and can be as fun as a casual game such as regular solitaire - then this is the game for you because it adds more than regular solitaire - a unique way to play the game along with a storyline to boot along with a well fantasy like OST and overall visual design.

8418805.review:
I think I snagged this game as a free giveaway from the developer. I didn't really expect to put 17 hours into it. I enjoyed playing this game quite a bit and go back to it from time to time. It's a solitaire game, so it's nothing mind-blowing, but it does have a few interesting features to mix things up. There are obstacles you need to clear to access some cards. It might not sound like much, but I felt it kept things interesting over playing standard solitaire. You can unlock a few power ups along the way also, which evolve the gameplay as you progress. Again, nothing drastic, but they do impact the way you play just enough. This is a casual game, so it won't provide any particularly strong challenge. 

There are little objectives for each level and 30 reasonably obtainable Steam achievements, though the pet collecting ones will take a bit of time. Achievements are really the only reason to raise pets. There's really not much story to it. I can't even recall the story at the time of this writing. 

Not much more to say about this. It's a fun game. A nice relaxing way to pass the time. If you like casual games and/or card games, there's plenty to like in Faerie Solitaire.

It's simplistic and rather long to sit down and play through, but, like Windows Solitare, it's a good platate cleanser to zone out on between games. 

PROS: Good zone-out game, decent graphics, combines skill and chance evenly. Improvements in Faerieland are actually useful and balanced, so it's not set in stone that having everything bought will mean all "perfect"s.

CONS: The pets you collect don't really do anything other than evolve and act as a sort of achievement. Also, there is no way to make it more difficult in story mode. You won't be getting all perfects but there's no challenge either unless you enter a separate challenge mode. It's fun for 30 minutes, but after that it loses it's novelty.

8186802.review:
Faerie Solitaire is a solid Pyramid style solitaire game with some unique twists to keep it interesting and fairly predictable story with decent voice acting.

Along with the card game, there are powerups you can buy, and eggs to hatch and raise as pets, which will keep you playing long after you've beaten the story mode. The challenge modes get progressively harder, and before long, they become real challenges.

The music is attractive without being overbearing, and the fanfares aren't too loud or jarring. The art is attractive and the game playes smoothly whether in full screen or windowed mode.

If you like solitaire games, this is a solid choice.

8183245.review: I'm kind of ashamed to admit to enjoying this a bit more than I expected. I was expecting a microtransaction-filled piece of shovelware. While it DOES have the usual "grind for near-meaningless add-ons" features, the gameplay itself is not that bad. The basic game is the solitaire game called "Golf" (probably known by other names, as most of them are). This game adds various special cards and rules that actually help expand the strategic depth of the game a little, which surprised me. I expected to try and discard it, but this is one I've come back to now and then. For its price, it's not bad. I'd have loved to see more than just one solitaire game supported, though.

There is one slight problem however. When I got to the point where I had played through the game a few times and was ready to move onto a new game I noticed there were two achievements left to get relating to collecting all the pets. So I thought I would play on to pick up those achievements. This is a sure fire route to madness; the egg drops are completely random so you could end up spending hours and hours of your life to no avail. The longer you spend chasing the last eggs the more invested you feel and the more difficult it will be to give up. So in conclusion this is a fun game but just ignore the last achievements for your own sanity's sake.

7967119.review:
Faerie Solitaire is a great casual game, which is well suited for wasting time in an enjoyable way.  The way the basic game of solitaire is made fun by the way the arrangement of cards shifts and the rewards system that adds a little dimension to an otherwise monotonoous game.  

The game was designed for an ancient monitor resolution of 800x600 and so is apt to look quite distorted on a modern widescreen monitor unless you play in windowed mode.  In that mode, the game window is small on a high resolution monitor and may cause some eye strain after long periods of playing.  So plan on short play periods when you are ready for a little casual fun and don't have time for a more serious game.

The developer promised in November 2012 that there would be a high resolution version released in the future and that all now current owners would get a free copy of the new version, which would have its own trading cards, etc.  So from a price point perspective, this game offers some trading cards now and potentially more in the future, which could be sold to further reduce the cost to the player.

7949138.review:
I'm kind of torn on Faerie Solitaire. It brings a new puzzle-based twist to the classic game of Solitaire. Each level has a new layout, and you have to follow the standard rules of solitaire to solve it in the most efficient manner. This is a pretty cool idea, but the problem with the game is everything surrounding that idea.
The structure of unlocking new levels requires you to perform specific challenges from previous levels, these start off easy enough, but eventually begin to get a bit more challenging. If you fail to complete the challenge, you have to re-do an entire set of levels, which is frustrating, but the challenges also aren't challenging enough to warrent such a stiff penalty.
There's also a pet collection aspect that ends up being more of a side-game, kind of like the flower garden in Plants vs. Zombies. However, anything that I unlocked just seemed really uninteresting and bland.
The story follows suit, with a swarth of poor voice acting, childish themes, and lackluster art.
The presentation and seems a bit cheap, as well... and it doesn't help that the game runs at measly 800x600.

Overall, there is a good game somewhere, buried deep down in the core of Faerie Solitaire. However, getting to that part can be annoying, and even when you do get there, everything surrounding the core game is poorly designed, making the whole package difficult to reccomend. I would say you should only check this out if you're REALLY into card games, and you don't mind digging through the bad parts to check out a fairly interesting twist on original game of Solitaire.

2/5 stars.

7932069.review:
The only skill you need for this game is eye-sight. It's a brainless time-waster. If you like those kind of games, you'll like this one too.

What you're doing:
At the bottom appear cards
You select a card that is 1 lower or higher than that card from the top cards
The selected card becomes the new "baseline" card at the bottom
If there is no +/-1 card you can draw a new baseline card
Do that until the upper board is cleared or you run out of cards

There is some fluff around that like collectable pets and a shop for minor game-mods.

7922419.review:
[TL;DR]
I would recommend this game for the casual gamer, those that enjoy playing a game at a relaxed pace or that doesn't want to dedicate too much time in one sitting. This also is an excellent game to play while waiting for queue-based online games, since it can be saved and stopped mid-round and picked up again at a later time.


[Full]
Playing on the traditional card game of Solitaire with a whimsical twist, Faerie Solitaire can provide a lot of play hours with the unlockables. These are the game-level power-ups that aid you in completing each round and pets that can be found, hatched, and grown as you play. The game, to me, has a zen-like soundtrack which made the experience, while playing or while it's in the background, that much more captivating. Each zone of the story lead to new game-play elements to plan for when trying to complete a round. The story, while minimal, includes artwork and a bit of dialogue. I believe this game to have a good amount of replayability, as each round is (seemingly) randomized.

7781541.review:
I initially bought Faerie Solitaire as a joke. My friends had gotten into the habit of buying each other embarrasing Steam games to clog up our collection pages. A discounted 4-pack for Faerie Solitaire looked like it would fit the bill. To say it backfired on me is probably an understatement.

Faerie Solitaire is a single-player card game where you have to clear a board of cards by matching them to the neighbouring number of a card on the top of the discard pile. It's simple enough, and the game does a good job of explaining everything as you progress. And with set goals, unlockable abilities and collectables that can be found as you play, there will be plenty to strive for if you want to obtain 100% completion.

The game's difficulty curve is mixed. Difficulty is controlled by goals that you need to complete along with clearing the board of cards. The normal level are well balanced for a complete playthrough. But if you want a challenge and you decide turn up the selected difficulty, you'll find that it ramps up very hard and very fast. And since this is a game dealing with randomly dealt cards, you'll find that some levels will be impossible to complete unless you get lucky with the cards you're dealt. Not ideal.

The game also comes with a story which I'd describe as unintentionally charming. You can see the efforts the developer has made in trying to build a meaningful story. But ultimately you'll laugh not because of an in-depth tale, but because the game feels like a 5 year old child that you need to patronise with a smile and a pat on the head. But that's not a bad thing. Ultimately the game is inoffensive, and it's conclusion may even bring a chuckle out of you with its self-directed optimism.

While it may not turn you into a faerie-believer, I recommend Faerie Solitaire as a fun distraction that will happily fill that 10 minute gap during the day where you're not really sure what to do with yourself.

Think of a Solitaire game with some silly Faerie story in it.  Luckily you can skip any of this story to get back to the cards.  There is some artwork in the background that may be related to the story, but just seems pretty arbitrary.  You can buy powerups to help you out a bit, but the game like most card games needs luck more than skill.

There is also a Pokemon type collect eggs and resources side game which is a silly distraction.  You get to "evolve" your pets by just playing the cards more.  

The worst thing about this game as you will read in the guides is the last egg(s) have stupidly low drop rates.  I ended up with 2.3million unused cash I couldn't do anything with.  I had a pile of useless resources and just playing the game trying to get an egg to spawn.  I can see why people set up a program to auto click this game while they are AFK.  Its JUST broken and really annoying.  Any goodwill I felt to the game was lost trying to get the last egg.  I do realise I could have just stopped playing and moved on, but I wanted 100% achievements.  I also wanted to EARN it vs some auto click cheating.
 For me I went through the campaign 3 times.

I'd suggest you just stick to the solitaire games in Windows unless you are nuts about fairys.

In the game’s “Adventure” mode, you play a young man who has the ability to free imprisoned faeries by playing 9 rounds of solitaire. As you free more faeries in different settings, more of the story unfolds through cutscenes shown between the areas. The story ends on something of a cliffhanger, showing that the developer intended to publish a sequel (although three years have elapsed since then).

7297335.review:
Faerie Solitaire is not a good game.

It's basically a slightly dumbed-down version of solitaire, with some fancy graphics slapped on and some sound effects to boot. All this stretched over an 12 hour long campaign of nothing but new backgrounds and a couple of uneventful cutscenes that try to tell a story but fall short in every respect.

Each level also has some objectives you have to meet, and if you don't then you simply have to retry the level from the beginning, over and over till you meet the objectives. There is also a challenge set, with 5 levels with different backgrounds and objectives that are in line with the Intermediate difficulty level.

Also, there are an excessive amounts of fairies (faeries, because it looks better) that don't serve any purpose to the over all game. Oh yes, and there are pets which don't do anything either, except add some sort of "replay" value to the game.

Steam Cloud support is needed here, but not included. There are 30 Steam achievements which are intertwined within the games user interface quite nicely, but I shouldn't really mention the achievements, because they are part of Faerie Solitaire's main flaw (read: bug that the developers aren't interested in fixing). Two of the achievements are related to the (unnecessary/useless) pets feature within the game, which is completely random and unlikely to work as intended. So expect an extra 20 hours of grindy gameplay on top of the already boring campaign if you want all 30 achievements.

Time to complete is around 12 hours, 35 hours if you want all the achievements. However, the more unlucky players could be made to sit around for 100+ hours because of the pet bug.

Faerie Solitaire is not a good game.

It's a pretty simple twist on solitaire - build up and down from whatever card is on the top of your pile, trying to get rid of all the piles (which change layouts in different levels). 5679301.review:
If you're a lover of simple, easy and mechanical game play, then this is the game for you. For 10 dollars, you'll have endless hours of Solitaire action. Its taken the classic game of Solitaire and turned it into an adventure. The game's story is easy to follow, has included collectibles so that you have a goal to work towards, and there are a variety of different modes available.

The only gripe is that some of the item drops are random, so you may have to do a lot of grinding in order to get certain achievements. There is one achievement in particular that is sort of "bugged", which may get in the way of those trying to get an easy 100% completion. It took me roughly 30 additional hours JUST to mop up the remaining achievements I was missing... which feels inexcusable.

Since writing this review, they have come out with a remastered version, which fixes some of the issues that this game had. Both versions are very similar though, and equally fun to play for some good ol' Solitaire fun!

I totally recommend this for some fun, casual play!

1487304.review:
This Game Is Really Good. It Takes The Well Known Concept Of Solitaire And Puts It Into An Intriuging Fantasy World. The Story Begins When You Are Tasked By An Old Wise Wizard To Save The Faeries From Imminent Danger But All Is Not As It Seems!
I Had A Lot Of Fun Playing This Game. I Played It So Much That I Got All The Achievements And Cards And You Will Too Because It Is So Addicting. Okay Let Me Break Down This Review:
Gameplay 10/10 The Gameplay Is Solid It Is Like Solitaire But It Has Interesting Puzzles And Powers You Can Unlock To Wreck Havoc On The Cards! There Are Cool Ideas Like Ice Walls And You Need To Use Fireballs To Melt Them. Overall The Gameplay Really Cant Be Beat.
Sound 9/10 The Sound Is Great And Really Reflects Real World Card Kinematics Like When You Draw A Card From The Deck. The World Sounds Rich And Detailed But It Misses Out A Point Because The Music Isnt Catchy
Graphics 8/10 The Art Is Really Great You Can Tell That They Must Have Had A Really Good Concept Artist To Work For Them. Although The Faeries And Everything Look Really Good It Misses Out On Points For Not Being 3D Graphics
Thats The End Of My Review I Hope You Liked It Rate It Up If You Did And Look Out For Future Reviews!
To Summarise
PROS
- Great Puzzle Solving Elements
- Faeries
- Lots Of Challenging Gameplay
- Realistic Card Kinematics
- Pokemon
CONS
- Doesnt Have 3D Graphics
- I Wanted To Play More!
- It Ripped Off Pokemon

This Has Been A Review By Hootie Please Rate Up And Give Me Feedback

1627619.review:
In between studying and other life callings, I often encountered the situation where I had free time, but not enough to get into a real game.  Luckily there was this game to fill up that free time.  Faerie Solitaire manages to be even more addicting than the real thing by both simplifying and complicating the original formula.  By removing the need to swap red/black suits and adding other methods to eliminate cards, this reinvention of one of the original time wasters has managed to eat up almost 10 total hours of my life that I may never get back, but never planned on using constructively anyway.

This game will not surprise you, (It's Solitaire, what do you expect?) but it will do it's job.  The story mode is just a framework for more time-wasting card-matching fun, and there are other things to keep you busy.  If you're looking for a reinvention of an old classic, Faerie Solitaire will give you exactly that.

4385770.review:
Faerie Solitaire is a card game at heart - a time waster.  It's not a hardcore game, it's meant for casual play.  That said, it does what it does well.  If you're going to play a card game on the computer, this should probably be it.  The audio is good, the animations are solid and enjoyable, and the gameplay mechanics are well polished and fun.  There are unlocks and pet evolving - everything a casual game should have to keep you hooked and make you want to keep playing.  There is also a MASSIVE singleplayer campaign of solitaire.  I beat the entire thing before reviewing this game and it took me a solid 7-9 hours.  That's right folks, 7-9 hours of straight solitaire - and I loved it.  The game functions well, does what it sets out to do in a great way, and doesn't try to overextend its reach.

If you're looking for a card game or a gift for a person who plays Windows' solitaire regularly this is the game to buy.  Don't buy it thinking it's something besides a time killer or a casual game.

Pros:

Good audio
Solid mechanics
Huge singleplayer campaign
Unlocks
Comboing is fun and addictive

Cons:

It's just a card game
When you complete one objective towards beating a level it shouldn't display that objective any more on subsequent hands - you'll know what I'm talking about if you play the game

As I said, it's a card game; nothing more, nothing less.  However, if you're looking for that, it's a great game.  It does take the main solitaire game and spin it a little bit creatively, but nothing too much to write home about.  One minor thing I would have changed is the way the audio works - when you go up the audio goes up, when you go down, the audio should go down.  But that's neither here nor there.  I rate this game average as it doesn't do much new, but if you want to play a card game I highly recommend Faerie Solitaire - B

1547265.review:
Faerie Solitaire is... yep, you guessed it - solitaire with a "faerie" theme. And that's more or less all there is to it, with a few twists.

As far as the gameplay goes, I don't know if this is based on a real type of solitaire card game or if the rules were made up specifically for this game, but it definitely is NOT based on the standard rules of solitaire that I know (e.g. the type that Windows solitaire is). It's much more simple. In fact, it's as simple as a game can possibly be. Seriously. All you do is choose cards that are either one value higher or lower than your "foundation" card. Repeat this over and over again, trying to build combos and clear all the cards from the screen. Card color and suit make no difference at all (which makes me wonder why the cards even have suits, but whatever). Aside from the need to strategize a tiny bit, which is required to get "perfect" hands (clearing all cards on the screen), not much skill or deep thought is needed. It's a very easy game. At least, the main "adventure" mode is. There is also a series of challenge levels available, but those are only moderately more difficult than normal.

Two additional factors distinguish Faerie Solitaire from being just a standard card game: the use of "power-ups" and the story that accompanies the gameplay. The power-ups are special abilities that can be unlocked using cash you earn by playing. For example, you can purchase the ability to see the next card on the pile, unlock additional "undo"s, etc. Power-ups are especially helpful later on when the requirements to proceed or attain perfect hands become a bit more challenging. The story plays out between hands in the adventure mode and involves some dude trying to save fairies or something... I honestly just kinda rolled my eyes at these parts because it was really kind of cheesy and pointless. It's not a game killer by any means, but it's also not really integral to the experience (title aside). The game also includes a bunch of collectible eggs that - unless I am completely missing something - don't seem to have any purpose... so I am really not sure what the point is in having them. One final negative is that the game only runs in a very low resolution.There are no options to change this, unfortunately.

So what do we have? A very easy, good-but-not-great (but addicting) solitaire game intertwined with a cheesy fairy-tale story. Though that may not be a glowing endorsement, this game does have a few good things going for it. If you enjoy mindless laid-back solo time-killers like solitaire, you will probably like this. It's perfectly suited to short pick up and play sessions. And while the difficulty level is low, in this case, that may not necessarily be a bad thing. It lends itself nicely to the laid-back time-killer vibe, but also coupled with the faerie story and collectible eggs, seems like it might be a good game for kids (I haven't tested this theory, but just something to keep in mind). If you don't care for solitaire in any form, nothing else about this game will change that for you. Otherwise, this is good as a mindless time-killer if you can pick it up on the cheap.

2379950.review: Faerie Solitaire is a game with a simple premise and an excellent execution.  While the gameplay is only a slight twist on the classic card game, Faerie Solitaire really shines by adding an interesting storyline, competent voice acting, and a wide variety of unlockables.  The unlockables themselves range from the merely cosmetic to upgrades that significantly improve success during gameplay.  Both the Steam Overlay and widescreen modes are supported.  To fully round out the package, several different modes of gameplay are included and the main adventure will take most players 10 or more hours to complete.  Considering the bargain bin price on this title it is a must have game for anyone who enjoys casual card games.  This game gets my highest recommendation.

2425199.review:
Re-writing my 2012 "review":

I was fortunate enough to get the game for free and it was in a Humble Indie bundle for at least $1 USD. Definitely worth that though past that, it's pushing it. The reasons are pretty simple.

It's solitaire and it beats the Windows version by a long shot in presentation and aesthetics but comparing a premium to a freebie isn't fair.

You can spend gold you earnt in rounds on unique power ups that help to get "perfects" in the game like destroying cards off stacks, undos and gold boosts.

There is a pet collecting system which feels tacked on. You find random eggs in-rounds but the chances are extremely low. There's actually people that resorted to using mouse scripts to getting their final eggs. You level up the pets so they evolve but they just sitting there in a picture form. Bad game design in my opinion though you could argue it was a "bonus" feature.

Subsoap tried to fit a story into this genre and while their efforts were noteworthy, I found it very uninspiring (though the voice actor was alright) and just skipped most of it. You just go around various stages and free faeries after meeting objectives.

So in conclusion, yes, I would recommend this game but only if you're a die-hard solitaire fan and the game is going for £1 or less. Not a penny more I'm afraid. Oh and it has trading cards, if you sell those, it's a nice discount on top.

925498.review:
The kindest thing I can say about Faerie Solitaire is that it's designed to let you bite off very small servings. From the time when you start the game, you can be playing a hand in about 15 seconds, and each hand takes just 90-120 seconds to complete. So if you need to kill 5 minutes but don't feel like waiting a full minute or two to fire up a larger game, this is a fine time waster, right here.

Having said that, it's not a particularly good solitaire game. It's basically TriPeaks with some variation to the layouts. It adds in grind features to compel you to continue playing, but these features aren't very well designed. Some of these features, in fact, add strategic elements to the game that actually make it less enjoyable, for me.

I'm prying myself away after about 4 hours. Friends who have finished it tell me it takes 12-15 hours. Can't do it.

Each level requires you to fulfill goals like getting perfects (all cards cleared), certain number of combos or money earned. 287515.review: I woke up yesterday with a hangover that could have brought Chuck Norris to his knees. After curling up in the corner and weeping softly for a few hours, I began to realise that I was in no shape to play Team Fortress 2. In fact, as I scrolled through my library I realised I needed something simpler, something softer, something gentler. I pondered Minesweeper but even that seemed a little violent. And then I noticed this on offer for a mere £1.36. It's surprisingly good considering all I expected was a solitaire clone. Don't get me wrong, this isn't the new Portal or anything. It is not without its flaws, but for that price, it's a great game to play when you're too Charlie Sheened to play anything else.

297665.review: There are three difficulties to this game: Normal, Master, and Impossible. I spent about an hour and a half playing on the Master difficulty. Master difficulty is really, really hard - but absolutely doable - if you're a new player, because the game expects you to have already played the game all the way through once. This is because the game works on a level and item progression, and it expects you to have a lot of pets and things made properly powerful before it lets you move onto the next level. Otherwise, this is definitely casual fare and very easy when played properly. However, if you're looking for a Nintendo Hard challenge, buy this game and play it right off the bat on Master. It makes the BIT.TRIP games look easy in comparison. Also, fairies and boring fairy related things, but it makes the humiliation I felt all that more deep.

885940.review:
All you need to know about this game to decide if you're going to like it? Look at the achievements. If the idea of a solitaire game with achievements (a bad sign to begin with) like "Destroy 20 ice walls with fire bolts" is appealing to you, perhaps this is the lone card game you need.

Not convinced? How about the fact that the only fairy I've seen thus far in the game is the smug douchebag on the King card. Other ranks in the deck have lizardmen, robots, and some kind of ooze-monster all waving happily at you.

Add in a pet system to grind XP for (I am not making any of this up) which does not tell you how to use it and asks you to set invisible creatures as your "Primary Pet" and you have the fever dream of card games. Suda 51 would make this game and fans would claim it was all to troll you. Except in the universe where Suda made this he had a head injury and a crippling addiction to purple drank.

I've still owned worse titles on Steam.

2336221.review: The presentation is a bit bland and so is the narrative, but Faerie Solitaire adds a series of new twists to the classic Solitaire formula making it fast-paced and exciting.

332359.review: Two brutal concepts combined for an unforgettable feast of blood raw gaming savagery. This ain't your pep pep's solitaire, and these ain't your grim gram's fairies.

2248191.review:
The mechanics of Faerie Solitaire offer lighthearted puzzle strategy.  Stages consist of nine hands with different goal permutations.  Each stage can be unlocked for non-campaign use and an extra set of challenges are provided.  Like the good casual game it is, you can play it in small spurts and have your progress saved.

"Interactive experience" people need not apply.  The story fails to enthrall and ends with an ad for a sequel.  Freed faeries are merely a repetitive click to continue.  Collecting and evolving pets is pointless.

Know that some stages involve completing at least one hand within a time limit.  I found this to be unnecessary stress in a casual game, but it never made me lose.

1381156.review: Don't let the name scare you off, this is a surprisingly fun game, and for the price right now it's worth grabbing.

1134798.review: Faerie Solitaire has kept me busy for 9 hours so far. It's your regular solitaire game with some more or less useless extra features, like the ability to raise some fantasy creatures, whose eggs can be randomly found under cards. Updates that directly influence gameplay can be bought and there's 30 achievements to get. Add to that some extra gameplay modes (challenge mode), and you have a pretty little time-waster. (Just don't bother with the cutscenes. Who cares about story? This is a solitaire game, dammit!)

259759.review:
I was pleasently surprised when I tried out this game. The game is very cheat and just a casual fun solitaire game, and I was looking for a really casual game that didn't demand much from the player, so I bought it. Later I found out that Valve recommended charging more, but the dev didn't want to.

There's a pretty long story mode where the levels get more and more complex (I didn't really follow the story). You earn money which you can use to buy upgrades such as undo and see next card. You also collect eggs that you need to grow into adults by playing. However, there's 32 eggs to collect and they drops completely random (I'm not a fan of random drops!).

I'll easily recommend this game to anyone just for an easy casual game.

1909808.review: You pretty much MUST buy this awesome game!

2717402.review: This is basically solitaire, and a pretty simple version of solitaire at that. The game's description refers to exploring worlds, raising pets, gathering resources, but this is all in the background and almost not worth mentioning. Each move you make earns you a little gold, which you can buy a few abilities with. There are 40 levels and each level has 10 hands, and each hand has a unique layout; also each level has a set of objectives that you need to achieve before moving on to the next level. This variety along with a few other quirks adds some strategizing that you don't normally get from regular solitaire. Computer solitaire is often only as good as how satisfying the sound effects are when playing and moving cards. This game has excellent sound effects, and on the whole is an enjoyable solitaire game.

3028867.review: A simple solitaire card game with a cute faerie story attached. The game has 3 different modes, so has loads of replay value. The story ending was a bit of a let down though.

2290713.review: I hate admitting I love playing a card game focused on saving Faeries, but hey I can't help it!  Faerie Solitaire is very addicting and offers a lot of gameplay for a cheap price.

2915527.review: This game is ridiculously addictive, especially when you like card games. Slight downside is that the gameplay remains very simple, ever after 3 hours of play and that this type of game, despite the nice graphics and unnecessary story, is best played on a hand-held.

2702068.review: If you're looking for something casual, simple and chock full of game play (and obviously, like solitaire), then Faerie Solitaire is the game for you.Story driven similiar to the hidden object and puzzle games, at the end of every level you advance the plot. The voice acting is suprisingly good and the artwork is cute. Also a couple of mini game type things to do as you go along in your quest.
